content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												I have had the pleasure to play this game for the last two days and I am not disappointed. I'll try to make this review as good as I possibly can.Lifeless Planet sends the player into an unknown world full of mysteries and puzzles to solve. You play as an astronaut (whose name I have sadly already forgotten), who was sent to a planet far away from earth. After having spent 15 years in a spaceship, the protagonist finally arrives at the already described destination but is quickly confronted with a problem: a lack of oxygen. This is where the game starts. My first impression: It looks nice. I have always been a fan of games showing an atmosphere that sticks with you for a while. This game probably is one of them, since it never ceases to amaze the player with nice-looking surroundings. Another aspect I really love about this game is the music and its voiceacting, whereas I would have loved to have more of both. The player gets to listen to small pieces of a conversation between the protagonist and a woman from time to time which I always thought were interesting. They give a small insight on the astronaut's past. The Russian audiologs were very cool as well. (9/10 for the audio. 10/10 if there had been more)The astronaut soon discovers a Russian village and - of course - can't believe his eyes and thus believes that he is back on earth and that he has been played a trick on. From this point on the player moves from one area to another, which usually are connected to each other by small puzzles. The already mentioned audiologs and documents help the player to understand where he is and what has happened. Not too much time in the game and you are confronted with a female inhabitant, living on the planet you are walking on. Your main aim from now on is to follow her and to try to get some answers to the many questions that are still open. Don't worry, at the end none of them should be left. The story was interesting to follow. At first I did not expect the documents to be able to tell a whole story, but now - after having played the game - I can say that I didn't have any problems understanding the plot. I find it very well thought out and would thus give it a 9/10.The graphics are beautiful. Of course, you can't compare it to other newer titles or the Crysis games, but that's not what the game developers tried to go for anyway. I was positively surprised by the many areas you walk through and are able to (partly) discover. It varies from a desert-like landscape to glaciers, waterfountains, lava, forests, and much, much more. Designing these many arials must require creativity which this game sure didn't lack of. The graphics fit the game just well, so I'll give it a 8/10Gameplay. That's where Lifeless Planet doesn't hold up to the price it is being sold for. I wouldn't say that it was not fun for me to play, not at all. There are many repetitive parts and puzzles which you usually soon get the hang of, but the different surroundings and dangerous, creepy traps made it a new experience every time. Nevertheless, most of it was rather easy to solve and I never really found myself in a situation, where I had to think for more than 5 minutes in order to find the solution for a problem. A big part of the game consists of jumping from platform to platform which - once you have required the extra boost for your jetpack - is really fun. The controls were the average ones which were not a problem for me (thus giving them a 10/10), whereas some other people have complained about them being too sloppy or unprecise when doing long jumps. All in all the gameplay could have been a lot better by adding a greater variety of puzzles and missions to solve, but the surroundings made up for it and I often caught myself simply exploring what there was - even though most of the times there was nothing worth to see expect a collectible mineral. 6/10It took me about 7 hours to play through the whole game, but I really tried to take a look at everything instead of rushing through one area to the next one. In another review someone had written, the author said that the game was too short and that the achievement for the first playthrough being under 4 hours was too easy. Well, I have to disagree. You can get many more hours out of it when really looking for the minerals (which are worth two achievements too by the way) and exploring hills and buildings. I believe that 7 hours for a 10€ game is a good deal. Let's come to an end. I definitely recommend playing Lifeless Planet when you are someone who doesn't need highend graphics or a moment of action every five minutes. This game is - in my opinion - made for people who are patient, who like to take their time and who focus on music and sound, because that's where the game scores. It sometimes reminded me and can be compared to a game like "Journey" on the PlayStation. It is worth 10€, but I probably wouldn't buy it for the original price, which is 20€. I hope this review convinced you to either buy or not buy this game. Thank you for reading.P.S.: The game scared me at some points. It was all good and fun though. :)

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												More than a review, this simply aims to be a collection of thoughts on my experience with the game.I was honestly very excited when I first heard of this title. Sadly, it didn't really live up to expectations.Not that it's a BAD game, it's just not consistent and often breaks the immersion and atmosphere. Which is a shame: this game would otherwise really do a great job in creating a haunting experience.One example:  roughly a few minutes into the game, after the impact, you find your oxygen levels are dropping dramatically due to a leak. After running to an oxygen tank, you will be able to fill up (and magically fix the leak) and be left with an autonomy of approx 8 hours.Shortly after that you will find your way to the Russian town where, among other things, you'll find another oxygen tank. Remember where it is, because you are likely going to use it more than once, as oxygen will run out within minutes and you'll have to track your steps back to it quite often until you unlock the next zone - which is where the game just resets its own rules: for most of the time your oxygen will last you days, with the exception of a few areas. You can argue that, as the game has cutscenes, you will have filled up in the period of time we weren't in control of him for - but there are plenty of areas you'll be roaming for a relatively long time without a worry. This may sound like a really minor thing to complain about, but it's one of many the immersion suffers from.Another aspect that feels often unnatural is that of puzzles: more often than not, the puzzles will feel completely irrelevant - you can safely pick up the green stones with your hands, but you NEED the robotic arm to place them in a slot roughly at the same height as your head, triggering a mini game. When you feel you might actually have found a use for the arm it won't be available for use, as it's only triggered when close to an object it is designed to interact with.The puzzles overall are never overly challenging, with the game mainly focusing on jumping, and simply feel out of place - situations that require you to interact with objects to actually clear a path are scarce, and when you do come up with a clever idea, the game just won't cooperate with you.It's not a bad design choice in itself, it just feels like the dev threw any potential the game had out the window.As for the story, it is obviously the aspect that should keep you playing the game until the end - but again, it starts with an intriguing premise and loses it's strength in the later chapters.What the game does achieve though, is in creating its atmosphere through haunting sound effects and a well placed soundtrack, which alone manages to keep the player on edge.Overall, I'd still recommend this if you can overlook it's flaws - the story is not without surprises, and the atmosphere it creates tries hard to make up for most of what the game lacks in mechanics.

content:
Posted: February 18
												The problem with this game is that it is story driven. But it lacks story. Like at all - not even bad story, it simply does not have anyWhat you get here is merely a theme park you walk/run through, a museum of random ideas, images and references mashed together in apprenent attempt to create "mystical" and "multilayered" story. The game tries so hard to get many meanings that it fails to get even one. Most of things you will see has no point, no connection to other things (aside of exteremly vague secondary associations, that will only appear if you have read and know well enough Aelita novel by A.Tolstoy. And even then, game had to literally point you out to that novel for you to even start recognising references.The thing that is called story here makes no stance on anything. It does not tell anything. Even main hero adventure on those planet rapidly degrades into total mess leaving you confused, scratching your head and thinking "what the hell was that?". And later on "and what was the point of all that?" because all weird stuff to happen will neven ever get any development.The only thing that is somewhat resembles a story is overhead out-of-screen portions of interview (you have heard half of it in the trailer) that reflects on the main hero story, but it is not every interesting (because you the main hero is just a walking suit with little-to-no personality you will find hard to care about) and yes, made into mess by making totally pointless and never developed references to the game content.So it lacks story and it was meant to lack pretty much everything else, including gameplay (it is slightly more complex version of Dear Easher and similar, gameplay wise), so yeah. But even here it manages to get annoying by horrible level design, especially closer to the end. Things like "if you die, you will respawn at last checkpoint facing the WRONG direction" (and keep in mind that many locations are quite barren and look-alike, so it is easy to get lost there) are true gems.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												With this game being one of the so-called "walking simulators" with very simple and straightforward puzzles which include placing object A in slot B, pushing buttons in specific order and jumping puzzles, it is the story, themes and setting that is making this game shine.Without giving too much of the plot away, I will describe first half an hour of the game, which will make it easier to talk about the themes that the story explores later on. You're playing one of the Astronauts sent to a distant planet that is thought to be filled with various kinds of life. With the journey taking more than a dozen years to reach it's destination, even though the spaceship is travelling twice the speed of light, the crew is put into a cryosleep. On reaching the planet something goes terribly wrong and a landing pod with all of the crew still asleep is crashed into the planet's surface. Some time after the crash landing, the protagonist regains consciousness only to find out that all of the crew is gone, landing pod is damaged beyond repair, his space suit is leaking oxygen and the planet itself turns out to be the wasteland with no signs of life. However after spotting and following the footprints in the sand you discover a derelict Soviet Union outpost, and this is where the protagonist starts to question if their mission was a hoax.With the game starting out as a more straightforward sci-fi thriller, especially after encountering a strange woman who can walk the surface of the planet without the need for a special suit with the supply of oxygen, even with the influences of the early science fiction films of the first half of the last century (particularly Aelita[en.wikipedia.org] and Woman in the Moon[en.wikipedia.org]) it is very interesting to watch how the game expands it's story into a more intelligent and thoughtful themes. If you're familiar with the works of the great Stanislaw Lem[en.wikipedia.org], particularly the ones that explore attempts at communicating with an alien intelligence (see: "Solaris", "The Invincible" and "Fiasco") you will know what I mean. Having said that, I also have to say that as other great pieces of art Lifeless Planet is using those influences to tell it's own story. With the main themes of game being the ones of ecology and how species interact with the biosphere; Fermi paradox[en.wikipedia.org] and the concept of otherness; and of course the story of the main protagonist, which ties it all together through his own personal loss in the past that he overcomes by finding out the story of that mysterious woman and the chain of events that led the planet to a state in which you found it.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												This is the first so called walking simulator I have played and I have to say I really liked (most of) it! Having said that, though, I do not recommend it (read on to find out way).  You spend most of your time exploring the world, occasionally jumping across gaps or pushing rocks but mostly just walking around. The few puzzles really aren't anything extraordinary and the solutions to all of them are immediately obvious. The real enjoyment comes from exploring the vast and impressive environments and finding clues about what happened to this world and the Russians who first settled it. The story is definitely intriguing and kept me entertained the entire way through the game, which is good, because the exploration part unfortunately becomes quite boring by the end of the game.  The first two hours are fantastic!  The last two to three hours, are mediocre and bland.Early on there are rock specimens, scientist logs, and intractable locations all over the place, but by the end of the game, there's pretty much nothing hidden for you to find. I feel the designer, by placing these items throughout the early levels, deliberately designed the game to make you waste time looking for something when there is nothing to be found. Either that or he just ran out of ideas for the second half of the game. I stopped bothering to explore about 75% of the way through the game and instead just kept to the obviously marked path since there was apparently nothing else to find or see in the giant open areas.There are a few areas where the game gets in the way of the immersion. These are only minor at first, but they quickly become more prominent in the late game. Two minor aspects break the game's own rules: oxygen that you only need sometimes and jet fuel that is infinite until you move into the next area. The major problems I constantly experienced were:- the astronaut sometimes hits an invisible wall that prevents you from progressing down an otherwise obvious path- a rock will look like something you can stand on but the game doesn't let you- the astronaut suddenly dies mid-jump because you jumped toward an area you are not supposed to be able to reach- when walking forward up a steep incline, if you jump you lose all forward motion and actually go backwards (this one is a huge annoyance considering how often you have to jump uphill)More commentary on that last major flaw... This game is a platforming game, and the fact that the platforming is broken is a huge dissapointment.  I was honestly getting angry at the game with how difficult the jump mechanics make it to follow an obvious path through the world.The story and environments start really strong, but they significantly decrease at the end of the game. If you want to experience a good story and uncover an interesting history of a fictional distant planet, then certainly give this a shot. If you want a good game, you are probably best off looking somewhere else.

												The game really draws you in with a pretty landscape and engaging beginning but quickly turns into simply running from place to place for 4 hours. Transitions are weirdly placed and so jarring that it will completely throw you out of any immersion. The puzzles can't really be called puzzles as a child could complete them, the only really difficult part of the game is not backtracking because everything looks the same. I know this game isn't supposed to be about gameplay and all about the story and while the story is interesting the logs are scattered too thin and in some places are quite hidden, however each log doesn't really add enough to make it worthwhile to search them all out. Having the logs read out to you while you are doing your running could've made the trek less tedious, but if you are an english speaker that's not going to happen because all the voiceacting is in Russian. Not worth 20, not even worth the 15 it was on sale for during the summer sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Lifeless Planet certainly sold me on a unique premise.  An American Astronaut lands on a planet 30 light years from earth, only to discover that not only did the Soviet beat them there, but that they've all mysteriously disappeared...And so begins what is probably the best 'Walking Simulator' I've played in the last three years, and all the usual suspects of the genre are here; diary entries, simple puzzles, no enemies, and most importantly, an atmosphere so thick and intoxicating that it just makes the games many flaws all that more tragic.  The majority of the games 'walking' involves linear pathways with simplistic jumping challenges and the occasional 'put the battery in the battery slot' puzzle, while gravity and vegetation serve as the games biggest threats.  It's certainly more involved than the other mascots of the genre, like Gone Home and Dear Ester.The graphics in particular deserve attention.  Specifically, they're terrible.  Even while playing on the highest graphical settings it felt like I was playing a game from the middle of the PS2 era.  Hope you like your worlds full of terrain morphing, because that's what you're getting, texture stretching on cliffs and all.  This plain geology is broken up with some simple rock models here and there, but it's no where near enough to fix how bland some environments feel.  The man-made structures are a mixed bag.  The simple utilitarian houses are well modelled and fit the theme well, while the larger structures are blocky and kind of silly looking.  The character models are also horrendous, and have such a cheap, low quality appearance.The games plot is also a bit of a mixed bag.  Earlier parts of the game sprinkle bits of character back-story on you, before deciding the to leave that arc alone until the end game.  In fact, so many plot points occur in the opening segments of the game that a lot of the middle section simply feels like filler.  On the other hand, this 'quiet' gives the game, and the player, a chance to take in the scenery, and with a full play through lasting three and a half hours, it's not that big a deal.Even with the visual and story pacing issues, I found Lifeless Planet to be a generally pleasurable experience.  It's aura of mystery and discovery kept me interested enough to see it to the end.  That said, it's a bit steep at $20, so you're better off waiting for a sale or bundle deal.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												If you're reading the 50/50 split on whether this game is "good" or not, consider that it may just not be for everyone.  I'd say the closest equivalent (which I surprisingly haven't seen referenced) is Journey.  If you enjoy an ambient experience where a story unfolds as you move through a unique landscape, this is for you.  The soundtrack enhances the experience, and while there is a good bit of jumping it doesn't really feel like you're playing a platformer.  If you are looking to point-and-click through things, or have high-action sequences, you won't enjoy this.  A $20 pricetag is on the high side, but I've paid more for less (and to be fair, less for more).  There's not really any replay value, but I've seen some pretty great movies I wouldn't want to watch either.  There are some people who are going to be really happy with this game - just know what you need from a game to enjoy it first.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												I bought this game on Steam because the premise intrigued me. Loading up the game had me crash land on a strange alien world. The first thing that struck me while playing, was how generic the animations looked. Then how plain the landscape looked. It never got much better. I do realize it is an indie game, but I have seen better from indie devs. The overblurring of everything just struck me as lazy.The story was not as good as I would have hoped. The small tidbits of information you find around the world as you explore are enough to keep you going, but ultimately it isn't enough. The developer may have thought so as well, as there is a very loose story about the main characters wife thrown in there. I cared more about the history of the planet, and who/what is on it than a character that I was never introduced to in the first place.With the amount of jumping puzzles in the game, the mechanics are decently done. However I had problems trying to get my character to turn around without running in a half circle and walking off small platforms. This mechanic if you were running could be explaned with forward momentum, but it happens while standing still which creates an artificial difficulty with some of the jumps. Otherwise the game does a good job of holding your hand at the beginning as less as you go on. Where you need to go isn't clearly defined, but I found myself instinctually heading the right way.Overall the game wasn't terrible, but I was expecting alot more. the zones and graphics felt too recycled for me. I finished it (barely) in under four hours, and that felt like a good time to stop it. It might be worth buying on a Steam sale, but if you are expecting Gone Home on an alien planet, you aren't going to find it here.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												I haven't finnished the game yet, so I can't speak to the resolve of the story as to whether or not the journey is worth it, but the game design is just poor.  The controls are a bit awkward, you can't strafe, but rather turn in a circle.  The levels are designed with extremely clear paths for you to take.  There are almost no puzzles in the game.  The only puzzles that really exist are jumping puzzles, and that's pretty much the only mechanic.  So if you like Parkour games in Minecraft, you'll love this game, but otherwise you'll find it extremely frustrating.  The terrain is also poorly designed.  There are many places where I just got stuck because the models were just a little too steep in an unsuspecting place.Thigs in the game are either extremely easy or extremely frustrating.  I don't mind challenging or frustrating games, but when 90% of the game is as easy as following the path, when it finally tries to give you a challenge that is above average in it's level of difficulty, it's extremely frustrating.  Lastly, some things are just kinda broken.  Most recently, I went up an elevator, realized I had to go back down to find something.  On the elvator ride back down, I decided to jump off to save time.  However, when I jumped off the elevator it stopped where it was at!  There was no way for me to get back up.  I couldn't reach it.  And "intentionally" the call button is broken.  So i've had to quit the game.  I hope when I restart the problem fixes itself.Frustration aside, the story is very intriguing.  I'm still very interested in seeing how this story resolves.  That said, the frequency of details begins to drop off dramatically the more you play the game.  It's nice to be left in the dark for awhile so you can try to piece things together yourself, but the developers have defnitely not mastered the art of witholding information.  If you withold too much your audience will be confused or bored.  If the gameplay was more creative and challenging (in a good, well thought out way) I would forgive the major pauses in story progression.  But it's not fun to put a story on hold simply because I have to follow a path for 10min.

												5/10So i like space themed games. I'm a sucker for that type of genre. The only thing space about this game is the Astronaut suit. If you replaced the Nasa suit guy with any other type of character(space marine or whatever), im pretty sure this game wouldnt have half of the recommended reviews that it currently has. I really wanted to like this game, and to be fair there were moments of brilliance shining through the cracks, but i just cannot recommend it. At it's full priee of 20  dollars its an absolute rip off. i know this game is on sale now for 10 dollars so it MIGHT be tolerable to some. but for $20 hell no. This game doesn't have that isolated open barren waseteland planet feel, infact its rather quite linear with very boring level design.  Buildings and houses  in this game resemble something you would see in a dreamcast game. To be fair i enjoyed the story and thought the ending was ok, but the pacing and the delivery of the plot was awful. and the transitioning between levels was so laughable bad, prolly the worst i have EVER SEEEN IN A GAME. It made it feel really unfinished. Your just walking along when the screen goes black with no sound, next thing you know your in a totally different area on yet another narrow path. Voice acting wasn't good either. felt cheap. Although i did enjoy the soundtrack, and they didnt over use it thank god. I really wanted to like this. and the only reason i beat it was because of how much i spent on it. Its been a day since i played/beat this game and i can vaguely even remember anything about it,  nothing stood out and made it memorable. There were no "Wow" moments.  Even if you buy this on sale be prepared for a repetitive, boring journey through what looks like an old dreamcast game with high res textures.(Not that there is anything wrong with old games, but you know what i mean)

												Lifeless Planet is a game with an excellent Sci-Fi story that kept me wanting to play this game more and more as I went on playing it. content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Lifeless planet is an adventure game with some light puzzle-solving.  It's ambitious, and most of the time it manages to acheive what it sets out to do amazingly well.  It's occasionally let down by "programmer art", so the graphics are uneven in quality. This can be jarring, but the eye shown for the composition of a scene means that much of the time it's a very attractive game, and often breathtaking.  The sound design is fantastic throughout and the score is used very effectively.It's almost completely non-violent, it manages to hit all of its plot points with only very occasional bum notes, and it has a jetpack that allows you to double-jump.  I love it.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Rich story, expansive world, and nice puzzles are contained within this game. The music was fantastic in its ability to immerse oneself into. The astronaut is the only playable character, and it sometimes is a little challenging to maneuver him in small spaces. This game also has lots of parkour elements into it, but is satisfactory in how easily managed the obstacles/ puzzles/ parkour can be. The "About the Game" section on this page does a great job of describing what you are up for.My only qualms with the game are the sensitivity of the controls and the seemingly low texture of the woman you are following compared to everything else. I bought this game during the summer sale for $16-$17. However, if I knew how great this game is beforehand I would greatly have paid the $20 for the game. 10/10 despite my criticisms. Would greatly recommend for everyone to try it.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												This is a great little game to pick up on sale. Its short (Has an achievement for finishing in under 4 hours), but is well worth a playthrough.Its graphics are average, but it makes up for it with some excellent music. It really sells the forlorn feeling of being alone on a dead world.The gameplay is simple, a combination of 3d platforming and simple puzzles. Its fine though, because you're playing this to uncover the story. Each scrap of dialogue and each found note leaves you wanting to find the next.I would suggest waiting for a sale for this game due to its length. Just know what you're getting, a short, simple sci-fi platformer game with excellent atmosphere, music, and story. A great way to spend an afternoon.

												Overall, I enjoyed this game. I have seen a lot of reviews saying that is it boring which I do not really agree with. It was not super action packed for very fast pace but it was enjoyable. I found myself at home with nothing to really do for an afternoon and this filled the void perfectly. It was a nice casual game I could play without having to think too hard really and hold my attention. Price wise $20 is maybe a bit much but whenever you see it pop up on sale I would definitely pick it up and try it. I loved the feeling of the planet and the enviroments felt large and looked amazing. The oxygen in the game seemed a little useless because I never ran into an issue where I needed it. Maybe if their was actually a timer going for it would add a little more pressure to the situation. All and all though I enjoyed the game and totally recommend anyone to play through it at least once.

Posted: July 24, 2014
												This is not a great game. The graphics are a bit dated (especially the one human character model in the game that looks like it belongs on a PS1), the story is bland and uninspired, the music is passable, the controls frustrating (platforming is not fun in spacesuit apparently), but this game does one thing very well. The game has a masterful sense of scale, Never since Shadow of the Colossus has a world felt so huge to me, and never has the character felt so small. Many areas of the game just feel astoundingly immense.This is definitely the game's strong point, and everything else feels very tacked on by comparison, but since it is short, I'd say it's worth the money if it's ons sale to check it out.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Easily one of the best games I've played in a long time. It's kinda Portal meets Shadow Of The Coloussus, lots of puzzle solving, platforming and exploration. There are also survial horror elements, but these only intrigue, and ultmately this game is more tense then scary. The game is full of clever twists, that I have never really encountered before. These twists are sort of similar to those of The Twilight Zone. While some would compare this to Dear Esther, this is far more engaging and mysterious, and while the graphics arent as good at that game, there is so much more depth to this. And you know, you can actually understand whats going on!This game is not an action game, and I am concerned this game will be dismissed, because it does not have the fast pacing of COD or *insert AAA title here*. Please give this game a chance if you are intrested. There is so much to discover here, and I had a real blast with it. Thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This gets a tentative recommendation, though in my opinion, this is a $10 game, not a $20 one.  Wait for it to go on sale, then buy it.*Spoiler Free Review*This is firmly an adventure game, and it uses its horror well.  You never have a way to fight back against the dangers of the planet, which works in the game's favor.  I was on edge the whole time, examining my path carefully to avoid dying horribly.  The game does host invisible walls, but with one or two exceptions, I never encountered them, focused on not being killed by the enemies lurking about.  To further play up the horror, you occasionally hallucinate through the game, which left me frequently wondering if what I just saw was real.The mystery of the first half of the game was phenomenal, as was the revelation of the planet's history, but this actually wound up working against the game.  The ending left me unsatisfied, and the twist revealed by the final document was disappointing.  I felt that it verged on pulling the game from Sci-fi to Fantasy, and after all that build up, it was a real let down.As you travel, there are set points where your jetpack fuel will run out (limiting you to just one boost, down from seven), as will your oxygen.  The oxygen is done to show passage of time, as well as to play into the story, and the jetpack fuel is done to present new platforming challenges, but both came off as contrived and pulled me out of the experience each time it happened.The controls work well on keyboard or controller, though a little bit more air maneuverability would have been nice.  Most of the puzzles are just a matter of finding the right object to drop into a hole, and the rest are figuring out a button sequence, but that's fine.  This isn't a puzzle game foremost, this is an exploration game.  The fact that the dev managed to make a linear exploration game not feel linear speaks volumes to his skill.The graphics leave much to be desired, but so long as you're looking at the surroundings, it works fine.  It's when you're looking at a facial expression that it becomes jarring.  Faces here always seem to be either neutral expression or vaguely malevolent, which makes the protagonist's description of what they were supposed to be expressing seem canned and insincere.I didn't get attached to the characters at all, and I can't help but think that had the protagonist's personal story been left out and the player been left to project on the character, the game would have been improved.  Without spoiling anything not already spoiled in the description, the mysterious woman had little personality.  Several scenes were thrown in to make me feel for her, and while one or two did make me feel horrified or confused as intended, I never managed an attachment.The level design is done quite well, though the transitions need a LOT of work.  Frequently a new level would start, I'd turn around and sit there wondering how in the hell I got here.  A few levels also felt that they were put in just to have them.  The fire level, or the hot springs level, for example.  The level in the volcanic area in particular was frustrating, as the game became one of guess and check to figure out which ledges were safe to land on, and which would kill you instantly.  A few times there were even invisible walls mid-air that would do the same.  Fortunately, the death system is done very well, or I likely would have stopped there in frustration.Overall, this is a good game, and it made me stay up far later than I should have to finish it.  A good story until the end, and I look forward to see more of the Dev's work in the future.  However, between the graphics, short run time (I finished it in ~4.5 hours), and lack of replayability, I don't feel it was worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												This game is trapped between being a classic sci-fi story and a platforming puzzler, and as a result it's not great at either. The platforming and environmental puzzles are not very difficult most of the time, and some of the hazards will almost never actually endanger you. The story was what initially drew me in and I enjoyed it much more than the leaping about, but it nonetheless suffered from what might have been a lack of focus: your character will remark on minerals he stumbles upon as part of a scavenger hunt type activity but not at all about the far stranger and more relevant things in the scenery, and too many of these intriguing-looking elements end up as mundane duds or get ignored altogether. Several other gameplay elements appear to have been added to create tension and the appearance of scarcity but the scarcity is scripted and you end up not caring. Nonetheless, the core concept is intriguing and is doled out well enough, with decent visuals, such that I wanted to keep going and see what was over the next hill, and ultimately did not regret doing so. On the whole I enjoyed Lifeless PLanet, chiefly for its story, but recognize its failings that may get in the way of other people's good fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												9/10 [SPOILERS] Despite the painfully slow start (in which i would've suggested adding more curious observations by our character about his crew or the 'alien planet' or possibly about his wife to engage the user), I was engaged into the campaign from the second we heard about the Green Fire and how it affected the soviets, then when we first saw the woman (whos name slips me) I was undoubtably hooked on following her and to find out who she is, or was. The second I picked up this game, I played the campaign straight until I was finished. The story just became so addictive that I really couldnt put it down without finding out *all* the answers. If i'm honest, this game felt and played a lot like Portal 2. Between the mysticism of the woman and the wrecked terrain with a beautiful past, combined with the small collections of puzzles ( -which I *really* grew fond of) I really enjoyed just admiring the story that was presented to me. The only thing I could nick at is that the wallpaper shown on a loading screen (the screen with the writing and mathematical equations) didnt really fit the story. "Three or Four crew?" really became redundant as after we'd met two of them and progressed far into the storyline.Generally speaking, this is one of the best story-driven game i've played since Portal 2. I'm really happy with how it plays and functions as more of an experience than a game (which, contrary to some peoples opinion is OK!) and would love to see more games like this in the future. (Thanks for bringing my attention to this game, KurtJMac and YogscastSips!!)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Lifeless Planet, while it is a very short game, is a game that exemplifies the idea of the adventure being more about the journey than the destination. WHile I wouldn't necessarily recomend it at its current price, it is still a very good story for those fond of very outlandish oldschool sci-fi.The only real complaint is the fact that it was blatantly not designed for Keyboard and Mouse primarily, in the fact that the camera will move based on the direction your character moves, always trying to face where they're moving. This isn't a massive issue, but it stands out nonetheless.To avoid spoilers, there are segments in the game that require the usage of geysers to lift yourself upwards. They are very finnicky in how they want to work, and if they want to work. This can lead to about five to ten minutes woth of frustration, but I do not feel this ruins the overall experience.Overall I would give the game an honest 7/10. Reasoning being that the game was very short, though I do understand that this was a kickstarter project, along with other small issues. Otherwise, this game is excellent for those wanting to be immersed in an interesting sci-fi world that gets more and more interesting as you progress, giving a very classic sci-fi vibe in the meantime.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This game is very... Special to me, as it tickles just all the right things for me. There is mystery, exploration, discovery, science and a little bit of horror in here, in just the right amounts to make this game feel increadibly atmospheric and fascinating. The actual "game" of it is a bit lacking - the platforming tends to be inprecise, I ran into a few places where I had to restart the game to get further and in some places, it feels a little aimless and you run around trying to figure out what to do. Still, I completely enjoyed unraveling this story and couldn't stop once I started. It's that good.If you're looking for a game that is absolutely brimming with atmosphere, chilling and very fitting music and a mysterious and interesting story, this is for you! That said, if you want smooth and responsive game play and don't care much for a story or a mystery - stay away! The gameplay is mostly walking, somewhat clunky platforming and simple puzzle solving.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Here's a short but meaningful disclaimer: If you're looking for an action-packed alien-fighting laser rifle-filled sci-fi adventure, try another game. This game is purely aethestic, and is no way meant to be combat-based. The game takes you, an unamed widow of a man, through an alien world where the Russians have somehow gotten to and destroyed the place (Yeah, go figure, the Russians ruined everything). Stranded and with an oxygen leak in your suit, you set out aimlessly for reasons unknown, probably because you have nothing better to do. The game's storyline is "Iffy" to say the least, the gameplay is boring and repetative... But that's the point. It's an art game. You enjoy the scenery. Believe me, as far as art games go, this is one of the best I've ever played. It's a lot like Journey, there's good music and good environment but it's really sandy and you just kind of do the same thing forever. Long story short, if you want an action game, don't buy this, if you want an art game that's about appreciating the long hard hours it took to but this absolutely stunning landscape together, then go on ahead. I give it an 8.5/10 as far as art games go. It's also a great time waster!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												This is a wonderful game. Clunky controls, (relatively) low graphics, and bland voice acting do nothing to detract from this game. A tense and suspenseful world, but also relaxing and beautiful. Moments of horror and terror, with only one path given to you: run. These moments are balanced by snippets of story delivered as you explore the environment chasing after two things: the truth and hope. This game made me care about the characters, but didn't wrench my heart strings. Lifeless Planet picked me up and carried me for a while, and when it was done with me, gently placed me on the ground for another game to takes its place. The story it tells is full of contradictions that build a wonderful place where you can take a break from the intense action other games demand you take part of. The game took me 5 hours to complete, and left me happy with my purchase of 20 dollars. Do yourself a favor, and play this game. You'll thank yourself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Lifeless Planet might be compared to recent titles like Dear Esther, since the main part of the game is exploration. Like Dear Esther, atmosphere is a key element to the game as well. However, Dear Esther was no more complicated than walking. While they are not necessarily difficult, there are platforming and puzzle elements to Lifeless Planet. Neither will rival a game specific to that genre but they are there and are enough to make the game interesting and varied. Graphically, the game is beautiful and the music and voices are excellent as well. The controls can be a little touchy at times, but not enough to be frustrating. Sometimes the path is not clear but again, with the little study, figuring out where to go will become apparent. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed the time I spent with Lifeless Planet and look forward to future games that David Board develops.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Lifeless Planet is certainly a novel idea, and although this review is a "recommended" one, this game does have its issues, and to be honest I can't really say I RECOMMEND it right now. I just feel that anyone who sees the red thumbs down on a review for a game that they like will just instantly hate on it without seeing what it has to say. Overall, I have mixed feelings about it. This is a spoiler-free review, so please read on.I'm not going to say anything about the story, except that the ending felt really unsatisfying for me. Other than that, I enjoyed it, and it certainly is a memorable experience... but it's just one of those things that I feel would work better as a movie than a game, at least in its current form. There is SO much walking without much happening, so many jumping puzzles which are made extra annoying by the walking mechanics--which make you move FORWARDS a little upon pressing S, before turning around. This has made me fall off of the edges of things countless times. There are very few puzzles and gameplay elements in between the walking, which aren't paticularly challenging... just dull.As for the graphics, they generally look a bit dated, but the skies and distant landscapes do look beautiful. The lighting isn't that bad either. However, I do seem to run into very random and inexplicable frame drops. (I have an i5-2500k and an AMD 7950.) Although this doesn't occur very often, one minute I can be getting 120FPS, the next it drops down to 15-30 in similar environments. Yes, I'm running on the highest settings, but my setup SHOULD be able to handle this game on the highest settings. The performance in this game is kind of unacceptable right now. Maybe it's something specific to AMD cards, who knows. I'm very disappointed with the performance in any case. Now, I love games about exploring desolate and abandoned things, such as in Portal 2 when you went though old aperture. That was honestly my favorite part of the game. Despite my frustration over the excessive walking and lackluster gameplay in Lifeless Planet, it managed to capture the same sort of atmosphere that made me enjoy the old aperture part of Portal 2.Really, whether I would recommend this game to you or not depends on your attitude towards "walking simulators." If you're one of the people who can tolerate Dear Esther, happy to just sit back and take in the pretty environments, then I'll hazard a guess to say that you will probably enjoy this game. If you dislike games where there is more walking than gameplay--in the case of Lifeless Planet, FAR more walking--then I would advise you to steer clear. To clarify, I am someone who dislikes Dear Esther, but loves The Stanley Parable--in fact it's one of my favorite games of all time. So I don't necessarily mind games where there isn't much "gameplay", just ones where there is too much walking without anything particularly interesting happening. Which is sadly, at least in my view, the case for Lifeless Planet.I'd like to state that I enjoyed the preorder demo, the sense of discovery when you come across that abandoned town and bunker is wonderful.  But unfortunately that's where it peaks. From there on out it's mostly pretty dull. I've been looking forward to the full release for a while now and I wanted so desperately to enjoy it. If the rest of the game was as interesting as the first few levels I could forgive all of its little faults, but unfortunately I found the rest of the game not necessarily BAD, but mostly disappointing. I bought this game for £8 from the humble store and I've gotten about 4 and a half hours out of it, excluding the time I spent on the pre-order demo. It had its good parts, and for that I don't regret purchasing it.Maybe you'll absolutely love it, I don't know, I'm not you. I'm not saying you shouldn't buy this, I just feel that someone needs to point out this game's issues so that they can be taken into consideration before you purchase it.TL;DR Lifeless Planet is a nice, pretty, atmospheric exploration game with an intriguing and original story--let down by excessive walking, lackluster gameplay and, at least on my hardware, unforgivable frame drops. If you have a tolerance for "walking simulators" then you may enjoy it. If not, steer clear.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Lifeless Planet has a creative storyline. The load speed of the game is amazing, all the while requiring little from the hardware.  The game while enjoyable is not as polished as you would expect for a final release.  I would consider it 'Alpha' quality.  The transition from area to area is often lacking physical continuity.  The music is well done, but needs more variety.   Obstacles and solutions seem placed directly in the player’s path & require little thought, which removes a level of depth from the game.  A frequent example of this is the jet pack charge-once it is depleted you know that all upcoming jumps will be small, removing a level of unknown from the player.  Character development is crucial for the player to become immersed in the reality of this game.  Too much time is spent on the technology development, and too little on Aelita.  You have the opportunity to develop a sense of sympathy for the planet, but very little for Aletia.  It would have been endearing to see the two parallel each other.  There are also small glitches with the PDA and claw.  I hope to see more games in the future from this developer.  On a scale of 1 to 5, with 5 being the highest rating, I would give it a 3.5.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Lifeless Planet is a interesting game that has some losing points that went along with it.First the good stuff. Music is well done for the most part with only a couple of tracks that seemed to be slightly off.The voice acting was good and the main character has a very smooth story telling voice.This game is an adventure game that is reminiscent of URU and as a person that like this style I like seeing more of these games.Story has some good bones to it.Areas for improvementWhile the story has good bones there are some things that are not well executed and can leave you with a feeling that you are missing something or they could have been better developed.It lacks some of the creative puzzles that are usual for this style of game.Graphics were a little low end, but for an indie game I am not really going to pick at this much.Lots of running, which wouldn't be a big deal if there was more stuff to find, but a lot of it just seems to stretch on without a payoff.Game length is kind of short and I think this could have been remedied by some more character development.Overall I enjoyed the game and it can keep you going as long as you can have some patience and if you are not too eager to have immediate gratification I think you will as well. As for the cost I would probably not pay full rate for it, but on sale I would definitely grab it. There is a lot of promise in this game and I hope to see more from the developer in the future. Just in case there is a question about my play time I watched my wife play it on her computer.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												I bought this for several reasons. I was hoping for that The Swapper atmosphere, spooky sci-fi. Some walking, some puzzles - jumping puzzles mostly, but still - no shooting stuff. The idea, and screenshots, seemed quite interesting. Also, the developer seems like a nice guy, answering the questions on the Steam forums and all. At 20 euro the price was a bit of a stretch, but I found it for 15 and decided to throw some cash.It is not as good as The Swapper. Lifeless Planet is basically an action adventure game, just without much action. Which is good. In good old days we called that a platformer. You crash on distant planet and then the things start to get weird, when you find a remains of russian base and one survivor who is not human anymore. I was expecting a spooky sci-fi, but didn't found the game that spooky at all. The visuals are quite interesting though, if you like to travel through some wastelands and ruins. The second part of the game was much better for me with more jumping and varied visuals.The game length is ok at 5-6hrs for your first playthrough, the only playthrough if you don't want to hunt for achievements. If you like wandering through deserted wastelands and some platform jumping action give it a try. If you prefer to run killing aliens stay away.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
 Review of the game "Lifeless Planet" from the director of Project Freelancer.This game is of particular interest to me, as it gives me pause from my own search.I will attempt to give a unbiased and partial review for this interactive audio/visual experience.Graphics: Nothing special, but the large scenescapes and visuals more than make up for this short coming.Controls: Standard platform game fare, but it needs the option to adjust sensitivity on gamepad controllers.Audio: The ambient music is something to behold, and is quite pleasent to listen to.Gameplay: I believe one of the games tags is "walking simulator". A fair description, but also add platforming.Replay Value: once you collect all the mineral samples, there's really not much motivation to go back.Overall: A good game that's worth its value, buick quickly loses value once you've found all there is to be found.Score: 7.5/10Notes: Please add the option to adjust gamepad sensitivity to the ingame menu for easy adjustment. Not just for the camera movement.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This gets a tentative recommendation, though in my opinion, this is a $10 game, not a $20 one.  Wait for it to go on sale, then buy it.*Spoiler Free Review*This is firmly an adventure game, and it uses its horror well.  You never have a way to fight back against the dangers of the planet, which works in the game's favor.  I was on edge the whole time, examining my path carefully to avoid dying horribly.  The game does host invisible walls, but with one or two exceptions, I never encountered them, focused on not being killed by the enemies lurking about.  To further play up the horror, you occasionally hallucinate through the game, which left me frequently wondering if what I just saw was real.The mystery of the first half of the game was phenomenal, as was the revelation of the planet's history, but this actually wound up working against the game.  The ending left me unsatisfied, and the twist revealed by the final document was disappointing.  I felt that it verged on pulling the game from Sci-fi to Fantasy, and after all that build up, it was a real let down.As you travel, there are set points where your jetpack fuel will run out (limiting you to just one boost, down from seven), as will your oxygen.  The oxygen is done to show passage of time, as well as to play into the story, and the jetpack fuel is done to present new platforming challenges, but both came off as contrived and pulled me out of the experience each time it happened.The controls work well on keyboard or controller, though a little bit more air maneuverability would have been nice.  Most of the puzzles are just a matter of finding the right object to drop into a hole, and the rest are figuring out a button sequence, but that's fine.  This isn't a puzzle game foremost, this is an exploration game.  The fact that the dev managed to make a linear exploration game not feel linear speaks volumes to his skill.The graphics leave much to be desired, but so long as you're looking at the surroundings, it works fine.  It's when you're looking at a facial expression that it becomes jarring.  Faces here always seem to be either neutral expression or vaguely malevolent, which makes the protagonist's description of what they were supposed to be expressing seem canned and insincere.I didn't get attached to the characters at all, and I can't help but think that had the protagonist's personal story been left out and the player been left to project on the character, the game would have been improved.  Without spoiling anything not already spoiled in the description, the mysterious woman had little personality.  Several scenes were thrown in to make me feel for her, and while one or two did make me feel horrified or confused as intended, I never managed an attachment.The level design is done quite well, though the transitions need a LOT of work.  Frequently a new level would start, I'd turn around and sit there wondering how in the hell I got here.  A few levels also felt that they were put in just to have them.  The fire level, or the hot springs level, for example.  The level in the volcanic area in particular was frustrating, as the game became one of guess and check to figure out which ledges were safe to land on, and which would kill you instantly.  A few times there were even invisible walls mid-air that would do the same.  Fortunately, the death system is done very well, or I likely would have stopped there in frustration.Overall, this is a good game, and it made me stay up far later than I should have to finish it.  A good story until the end, and I look forward to see more of the Dev's work in the future.  However, between the graphics, short run time (I finished it in ~4.5 hours), and lack of replayability, I don't feel it was worth the price of admission.

												Overall, I enjoyed this game. I have seen a lot of reviews saying that is it boring which I do not really agree with. content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												This is not a great game. The graphics are a bit dated (especially the one human character model in the game that looks like it belongs on a PS1), the story is bland and uninspired, the music is passable, the controls frustrating (platforming is not fun in spacesuit apparently), but this game does one thing very well. The game has a masterful sense of scale, Never since Shadow of the Colossus has a world felt so huge to me, and never has the character felt so small. Many areas of the game just feel astoundingly immense.This is definitely the game's strong point, and everything else feels very tacked on by comparison, but since it is short, I'd say it's worth the money if it's ons sale to check it out.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Easily one of the best games I've played in a long time. It's kinda Portal meets Shadow Of The Coloussus, lots of puzzle solving, platforming and exploration. There are also survial horror elements, but these only intrigue, and ultmately this game is more tense then scary. The game is full of clever twists, that I have never really encountered before. These twists are sort of similar to those of The Twilight Zone. While some would compare this to Dear Esther, this is far more engaging and mysterious, and while the graphics arent as good at that game, there is so much more depth to this. And you know, you can actually understand whats going on!This game is not an action game, and I am concerned this game will be dismissed, because it does not have the fast pacing of COD or *insert AAA title here*. Please give this game a chance if you are intrested. There is so much to discover here, and I had a real blast with it. Thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This gets a tentative recommendation, though in my opinion, this is a $10 game, not a $20 one.  Wait for it to go on sale, then buy it.*Spoiler Free Review*This is firmly an adventure game, and it uses its horror well.  You never have a way to fight back against the dangers of the planet, which works in the game's favor.  I was on edge the whole time, examining my path carefully to avoid dying horribly.  The game does host invisible walls, but with one or two exceptions, I never encountered them, focused on not being killed by the enemies lurking about.  To further play up the horror, you occasionally hallucinate through the game, which left me frequently wondering if what I just saw was real.The mystery of the first half of the game was phenomenal, as was the revelation of the planet's history, but this actually wound up working against the game.  The ending left me unsatisfied, and the twist revealed by the final document was disappointing.  I felt that it verged on pulling the game from Sci-fi to Fantasy, and after all that build up, it was a real let down.As you travel, there are set points where your jetpack fuel will run out (limiting you to just one boost, down from seven), as will your oxygen.  The oxygen is done to show passage of time, as well as to play into the story, and the jetpack fuel is done to present new platforming challenges, but both came off as contrived and pulled me out of the experience each time it happened.The controls work well on keyboard or controller, though a little bit more air maneuverability would have been nice.  Most of the puzzles are just a matter of finding the right object to drop into a hole, and the rest are figuring out a button sequence, but that's fine.  This isn't a puzzle game foremost, this is an exploration game.  The fact that the dev managed to make a linear exploration game not feel linear speaks volumes to his skill.The graphics leave much to be desired, but so long as you're looking at the surroundings, it works fine.  It's when you're looking at a facial expression that it becomes jarring.  Faces here always seem to be either neutral expression or vaguely malevolent, which makes the protagonist's description of what they were supposed to be expressing seem canned and insincere.I didn't get attached to the characters at all, and I can't help but think that had the protagonist's personal story been left out and the player been left to project on the character, the game would have been improved.  Without spoiling anything not already spoiled in the description, the mysterious woman had little personality.  Several scenes were thrown in to make me feel for her, and while one or two did make me feel horrified or confused as intended, I never managed an attachment.The level design is done quite well, though the transitions need a LOT of work.  Frequently a new level would start, I'd turn around and sit there wondering how in the hell I got here.  A few levels also felt that they were put in just to have them.  The fire level, or the hot springs level, for example.  The level in the volcanic area in particular was frustrating, as the game became one of guess and check to figure out which ledges were safe to land on, and which would kill you instantly.  A few times there were even invisible walls mid-air that would do the same.  Fortunately, the death system is done very well, or I likely would have stopped there in frustration.Overall, this is a good game, and it made me stay up far later than I should have to finish it.  A good story until the end, and I look forward to see more of the Dev's work in the future.  However, between the graphics, short run time (I finished it in ~4.5 hours), and lack of replayability, I don't feel it was worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												I bought this for several reasons. I was hoping for that The Swapper atmosphere, spooky sci-fi. Some walking, some puzzles - jumping puzzles mostly, but still - no shooting stuff. The idea, and screenshots, seemed quite interesting. Also, the developer seems like a nice guy, answering the questions on the Steam forums and all. At 20 euro the price was a bit of a stretch, but I found it for 15 and decided to throw some cash.It is not as good as The Swapper. Lifeless Planet is basically an action adventure game, just without much action. Which is good. In good old days we called that a platformer. You crash on distant planet and then the things start to get weird, when you find a remains of russian base and one survivor who is not human anymore. I was expecting a spooky sci-fi, but didn't found the game that spooky at all. The visuals are quite interesting though, if you like to travel through some wastelands and ruins. The second part of the game was much better for me with more jumping and varied visuals.The game length is ok at 5-6hrs for your first playthrough, the only playthrough if you don't want to hunt for achievements. If you like wandering through deserted wastelands and some platform jumping action give it a try. If you prefer to run killing aliens stay away.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
 Review of the game "Lifeless Planet" from the director of Project Freelancer.This game is of particular interest to me, as it gives me pause from my own search.I will attempt to give a unbiased and partial review for this interactive audio/visual experience.Graphics: Nothing special, but the large scenescapes and visuals more than make up for this short coming.Controls: Standard platform game fare, but it needs the option to adjust sensitivity on gamepad controllers.Audio: The ambient music is something to behold, and is quite pleasent to listen to.Gameplay: I believe one of the games tags is "walking simulator". A fair description, but also add platforming.Replay Value: once you collect all the mineral samples, there's really not much motivation to go back.Overall: A good game that's worth its value, buick quickly loses value once you've found all there is to be found.Score: 7.5/10Notes: Please add the option to adjust gamepad sensitivity to the ingame menu for easy adjustment. Not just for the camera movement.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												First off, I want to say; this game is worth the $20 I spent. I started slow, though I sped up a bit towards the end. It took me about 4 hours to complete. This is a beautiful game, minus the "human" models and animations. This is not the prettiest game I have ever seen, but the devs obviously took the time to get it right. Atmosphere is the name of the game here; the sound effects are great, the music is fantastic. Voice acting is average. The experience was wonderful, creepy, and played to my inner conspiracy-theorist. I played with maxed-out settings (with an EVGA 760) and only encountered frame rate drops when confronted with scaffolding; a little confusing, as this is not a GPU-heavy game. However, there are elements in the game that seem almost like an after-thought; oxygen hunting, some of the puzzles. I did not get stuck on any of the puzzles, although I will say this; the platforming was weak. Not weak because it was so simple a 2 year-old could do it, but weak because the controls were not as responsive as they could have been. It almost seemed like there was an element of momentum to the jumping, but it did not always work. Sometimes I had to run in circles a bit before I took the running leap. That being said, I did not play with k/m. I used a gamepad to play, as it felt more natural in this case. I'm not sure if my troubles were because of my use of a gamepad, so I would not hold it against the devs.Overall; this was a 9/10.These guys know how it's done. If you think that $20 is too much for a 4-6 hour experience, try to remember the last time you went to see an IMAX movie. How much did you spend? Maybe $20 - $30? That experience probably lasted only an hour and a half. There is a lot to be seen here, a lot to be admired. They did a fantastic job, and I hope they make more games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Lifeless Planet is a peculiar game. On one hand it has that endemic lack of tact in the writing that indie games seem to all share and the production values (for the most part) are sorely lacking at times, but I still found myself playing through it and enjoying it. "Just one more level" was a frequently thought of phrase while playing the game and the source of it was wanting to have closure on the game's narrative.There's nothing but walking around, platforming and a few simple puzzles (obstacles would be a better description of the puzzles really) and it works for the most part. It is almost woefully simple and linear but the story and a few of the enviroments, though plain, makes Lifeless Planet an oddly engrossing and pretty game. I was disappointed at the rather weak visual design but it still fulfilled my urge of walking on an alien planet in a videogame; I just wished it was better realized.The music is good but I felt that it tried too hard to be the source of emotion instead of complementing the game, which brings me to a point that nagged me for most of the game. The game, though it tried, didn't really succeed when it tried to be meaningful. Sure there were a few moments that piqued my interest but I felt it was too vague and/or lacked tact when it tried to say something about the situation and the protagonist's motivations. What the story does well enough is that it hooked me into wanting to know more about it, thus pushing me into playing for longer sessions that I wouldn't have otherwise. In another note, the atmosphere was surprisingly good. While I won't call it a horror game, it did an ok job of setting the right amount of tension you'd expect in the same situation. Again, I just wish it was better realized but it still did the job.In the end, I can recommend the game to people that can look over the plainness and low budget of the game but that think it'd be interesting to explore a planet. While I wouldn't pay full price for it (got it during Steam's Summer Adventure 2014 Sale) it's still a solid and interesting enough of a game for that very specific niche of players.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This gets a tentative recommendation, though in my opinion, this is a $10 game, not a $20 one.  Wait for it to go on sale, then buy it.*Spoiler Free Review*This is firmly an adventure game, and it uses its horror well.  You never have a way to fight back against the dangers of the planet, which works in the game's favor.  I was on edge the whole time, examining my path carefully to avoid dying horribly.  The game does host invisible walls, but with one or two exceptions, I never encountered them, focused on not being killed by the enemies lurking about.  To further play up the horror, you occasionally hallucinate through the game, which left me frequently wondering if what I just saw was real.The mystery of the first half of the game was phenomenal, as was the revelation of the planet's history, but this actually wound up working against the game.  The ending left me unsatisfied, and the twist revealed by the final document was disappointing.  I felt that it verged on pulling the game from Sci-fi to Fantasy, and after all that build up, it was a real let down.As you travel, there are set points where your jetpack fuel will run out (limiting you to just one boost, down from seven), as will your oxygen.  The oxygen is done to show passage of time, as well as to play into the story, and the jetpack fuel is done to present new platforming challenges, but both came off as contrived and pulled me out of the experience each time it happened.The controls work well on keyboard or controller, though a little bit more air maneuverability would have been nice.  Most of the puzzles are just a matter of finding the right object to drop into a hole, and the rest are figuring out a button sequence, but that's fine.  This isn't a puzzle game foremost, this is an exploration game.  The fact that the dev managed to make a linear exploration game not feel linear speaks volumes to his skill.The graphics leave much to be desired, but so long as you're looking at the surroundings, it works fine.  It's when you're looking at a facial expression that it becomes jarring.  Faces here always seem to be either neutral expression or vaguely malevolent, which makes the protagonist's description of what they were supposed to be expressing seem canned and insincere.I didn't get attached to the characters at all, and I can't help but think that had the protagonist's personal story been left out and the player been left to project on the character, the game would have been improved.  Without spoiling anything not already spoiled in the description, the mysterious woman had little personality.  Several scenes were thrown in to make me feel for her, and while one or two did make me feel horrified or confused as intended, I never managed an attachment.The level design is done quite well, though the transitions need a LOT of work.  Frequently a new level would start, I'd turn around and sit there wondering how in the hell I got here.  A few levels also felt that they were put in just to have them.  The fire level, or the hot springs level, for example.  The level in the volcanic area in particular was frustrating, as the game became one of guess and check to figure out which ledges were safe to land on, and which would kill you instantly.  A few times there were even invisible walls mid-air that would do the same.  Fortunately, the death system is done very well, or I likely would have stopped there in frustration.Overall, this is a good game, and it made me stay up far later than I should have to finish it.  A good story until the end, and I look forward to see more of the Dev's work in the future.  However, between the graphics, short run time (I finished it in ~4.5 hours), and lack of replayability, I don't feel it was worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Lifeless Planet has a creative storyline. The load speed of the game is amazing, all the while requiring little from the hardware.  The game while enjoyable is not as polished as you would expect for a final release.  I would consider it 'Alpha' quality.  The transition from area to area is often lacking physical continuity.  The music is well done, but needs more variety.   Obstacles and solutions seem placed directly in the player’s path & require little thought, which removes a level of depth from the game.  A frequent example of this is the jet pack charge-once it is depleted you know that all upcoming jumps will be small, removing a level of unknown from the player.  Character development is crucial for the player to become immersed in the reality of this game.  Too much time is spent on the technology development, and too little on Aelita.  You have the opportunity to develop a sense of sympathy for the planet, but very little for Aletia.  It would have been endearing to see the two parallel each other.  There are also small glitches with the PDA and claw.  I hope to see more games in the future from this developer.  On a scale of 1 to 5, with 5 being the highest rating, I would give it a 3.5.
