number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												This game could really go either way in the recommendations department; on one hand, it's an original, indy game that stresses some of the best and possibly most interesting features of an original concept. It's interesting in the same way the "mystery box" of horror or suspense is, and offers some interesting thoughts. I'd love to see more support for indy games, but...On the other hand, the game failes to follow through on those interesting thoughts. The platforming and controls are absurdedly weak for a game that relies on it. The movement, jetpacking, and other actions get old really fast, and this is for a game that boasts an achievement for completing the game in less than 4 hours on the first playthough. Half the puzzles are exactly the same as previous puzzles, and the other half feel inane and time-wasting. The protaganist is hardly there; rather than telling a story about his wife (as hinted at in the trailer), it becomes the story by lack of any competion, as we learn nothing about her besides her death and his nihlism; he leaves two crewmembers dead without a backward glance, ignoring a story about loss and space (especially in the context of a one-way journey where they likely expected to learn, live, and die together); he ends up following a ridiculously slow genetically altered Russian without ever discovering a way to talk with her and prompt any kind of story. In all, the game could be worthwhile as part of a bundle (Yay Humble Bundle!) but terrible as an individual game. maybe 1.5/5 stars. Watch the videos on YouTube if you want to learn the "story"; GameKiller346 posted 8 videos that cover the whole thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												My score: 2/10I should have known what I would think of the game from my first impression - I couldn't get the main menu to work correctly! I could highlight New Game, but was unable to access the Options menu. After playing the game for a little bit, I would go to the menu and was unable to access the "Save & Quit" option. I basically had to just wait until I got to a save point and then Ctrl+Alt+Delete to the Task Manager and End Task to quit the game... This was only the beginning.Game Mechanics were a big issue for me, which makes it even more problematic knowing that this is a platformer from start to finish. Timing the jumps is part of the game, but basically missing a jump means dying and dying means restarting, A LOT. But then there are other problems with the game mechanics. There is a part where you have to use geysers to jump from place to place. Although, I was finally able to get through it (simply by luck), I was never able to figure out how the mechanic actually worked to make it happen. Basically, I just kept pushing buttons and after 50 attempts, I'd finally make it. Additional problems are that this was an obvious port from X-Box (still had places to push X or Y buttons), that was badly adapted to a keyboard and mouse. Finally, there were levels that I was able to complete without doing (what I would think are) necessary actibities.  Don't want to spoil the game, but in multiple levels there are these huge machines to turn on to get from one point to another. I went explorting before doing this and managed to reach the end of the level. This is just poor level design. In a game that is all about exploring, I should be able to explore myself out of a level without doing crucial steps.The puzzles were a bit interesting. The problem was that they were generally the same puzzles time after time after time with very little variation between them. This almost seemed like cheating to me. Pick up stone, use it to power a machine. Walk for five minutes, pick up stone, use it to power another machine. Rinse, lather, repeat about 20 times. Opening doors? Find a code from six buttons. Next door? Same 6 buttons but in a different order. Next door? Guess what? Same 6 buttons but in a different order. This same puzzle for about 6-8 doors.The most annoying part of the game was all the pointless dying. There were areas where it is difficult to tell where you could and could not go, but if you went to a area you were not supposed to go to, you died. Restart. One level (without giving too much away) sees the player navigating through volcanic activity. This level took me a good 30-45 minutes to navigate because I could not tell what was going to kill me and what wouldn't kill me. By the time I finally got through it, I was so frustrated, I wanted to delete the game. Another part of the game involves plants killing you by coming out of the ground and there was no telling (other than dying) where some of them would appear from. It got annoying because I was frequently not even close to a clump of plants, but still managed to die by getting spiked. Restart.The story was somewhat interesting. It was the only thing that made me play through the game to the finish. However, it was so anti-climactic that I was disappointed when I finally finished it. Not even the world made want to keep gonig. I did not really find myself once thinking, I wonder what's around that corner, but wondered many times, what is THAT supposed to be? There was one level that (I think) had a glacier or ice on it, but it was so poorly implemented I don't know what it was. The biggest problem with the landscape development was that the rocky outcroppings and "boundaries" of the level were supposed to be stone, but looked smooth instead of rough and rock-like. Was it worth $20.00? Not even close. It took me roughly 6 hours to win the game and with all the problems described above, I'm not sure I'd really even pay $5.00 for the game. Maybe $1.99 if I had a free afternoon on a random Satruday. The only reason this did not get a 1/10 is because there weren't any game breaking bugs nor anytime the game crashed to desktop. So at least they got that right.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Lifeless Planet is unfortunately a game thay lived up to its title. Lifeless. Dull. Uninteresting. Which is quite a shame, as it looked very promising all the way up to the second fourth of the story. After that, the puzzles start to feel repetitive, the platforming gets mind numbing, and the story falls on its face. Honestly, the story was the most damning part. Specifically, it tripped on its boring plot twist and landed on its face in an anticlimactic ending that felt unfulfilling. If I can give this game points, the story up until the plot twist/villain reveal was amazing. They knew how to set up everything. Which is exactly why the mediocreness the rest of the game displayed makes this game feel unfulfilling. It created a mysterious and scary atmosphere splendidly. It felt open when it needed to and claustrophobic at the right moments. But then it feels like they tacked on everything afterwards almost like an afterthought. It also doesn't really have any replayability for such a short game. I finished the story in 6 hours! This game wasn't awful, but it was very unsatisfying.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Lifeless Planet certainly sold me on a unique premise.  An American Astronaut lands on a planet 30 light years from earth, only to discover that not only did the Soviet beat them there, but that they've all mysteriously disappeared...And so begins what is probably the best 'Walking Simulator' I've played in the last three years, and all the usual suspects of the genre are here; diary entries, simple puzzles, no enemies, and most importantly, an atmosphere so thick and intoxicating that it just makes the games many flaws all that more tragic.  The majority of the games 'walking' involves linear pathways with simplistic jumping challenges and the occasional 'put the battery in the battery slot' puzzle, while gravity and vegetation serve as the games biggest threats.  It's certainly more involved than the other mascots of the genre, like Gone Home and Dear Ester.The graphics in particular deserve attention.  Specifically, they're terrible.  Even while playing on the highest graphical settings it felt like I was playing a game from the middle of the PS2 era.  Hope you like your worlds full of terrain morphing, because that's what you're getting, texture stretching on cliffs and all.  This plain geology is broken up with some simple rock models here and there, but it's no where near enough to fix how bland some environments feel.  The man-made structures are a mixed bag.  The simple utilitarian houses are well modelled and fit the theme well, while the larger structures are blocky and kind of silly looking.  The character models are also horrendous, and have such a cheap, low quality appearance.The games plot is also a bit of a mixed bag.  Earlier parts of the game sprinkle bits of character back-story on you, before deciding the to leave that arc alone until the end game.  In fact, so many plot points occur in the opening segments of the game that a lot of the middle section simply feels like filler.  On the other hand, this 'quiet' gives the game, and the player, a chance to take in the scenery, and with a full play through lasting three and a half hours, it's not that big a deal.Even with the visual and story pacing issues, I found Lifeless Planet to be a generally pleasurable experience.  It's aura of mystery and discovery kept me interested enough to see it to the end.  That said, it's a bit steep at $20, so you're better off waiting for a sale or bundle deal.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												Even though the character design and some the graphics aren't the most amazing looking, this game will greatly impress you if you are a fan of Sci-Fi.  The story feels like something out of Golden Era sci-fi and has some interesting Alternate History (maybe?) ideas it plays with.  The landscapes are also very simple but very beautiful, where it can sometimes get distracting moving from objective to objective.  The gameplay however is where the game does falter, with controls similar to old-school Tomb Raider where it feels like you are moving a tank.  If you do get stuck however the checkpoint system is a good way to restart, and get unstuck.  Its a good afternoon game to play through and plays comfortably on a controller.  I wouldn't mind seeing a prequel or sequal, but the story does a good job of wrapping itself up while still allowing you to wonder on the few strings left untied.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												A nice atmospheric story-rich simple game. It's not much game-play wise: you switch by just wandering around, balancing on tall structures, and jumping through rocks and platforms. There are a few very simple puzzles. The jumping part is fun, accompanied by low gravity.The atmosphere is spot on. Nice dark ambient soundtrack and visuals are unique, and good looking, although there could be more detail in certain more monotonic geographical areas of the game. The story is very good, rich in mystery and even emotion. In addition to the story there are some collectibles, which surprised me as they were accompanied by some intelligent information. The game world is divided into many short levels, all of which are very varied and some are absolutely astonishing in terms of atmosphere and visuals.The game is short and can be finished in five hours, unless you (like me) get drawn in by the atmosphere and want to explore every corner. Suggested to people who like post apocalyptic atmosphere and mystery.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												What started as an interesting story and challenging physics platformer, ended in cliche' sci-fi and aggrivating controls. The story progressed hastily and haphazardly, culminating in random information being thrown in at the last minute. All of it given great importance in an attempt attempt to explain the strange turns the story would take.The controls can be very unreliable.  Moments requiring precision are completed more with luck rather than skill, the camera does everything it can to fight you, resulting in alternative paths(even neccessary paths) blocked, hidden, or difficult to get to.  The player can turn on a dime or require huge turning arcs.  Either happening at any moment, but usually not when you really need it.  Turning left on a rock can find your character swerving off the edge, where turning right can see you spinning in place.  Landing on the same rock in a slightly different position, can yield different results.The saving system is unreliable at best.  Several times I would return to the game to find my character standing somewhere he had been ages ago, and having to plow through areas I had already completed just to progress the story(even having seen the game save my progress up to the point I remember).  Though, there were also several moments where the game would lead to a dead end, which was actually the end of the level.  The screen would fade to black and return with you standing in a completely different and unrelated area.  Also, the camera is notorious for loading with you pointing or facing in the wrong direction.  One zone you can load with your character facing the right way but not the camera, the next, the camera is facing the right way but not your character.  When loading new areas that don't start at a wall similar to one the last zone ended with, you can find yourself exploring the "dead end" of a level's starting area.  Forcing you to turn around and trudge back up the way you came in order to advance.Eventually I found myself towards the end of the game, pushing forward simply with the belief that I was almost done.  Thankfuly the strange turns happened in quick succesion and I found myself looking at the portal home.  I find myself disappointed at how the game and story turned out, and ashamed that my own stubborness drove me to finish it.  But, I'm glad its finally over and I can retire this title to the graveyard never to be touched again.

Watch the videos on YouTube if you want to learn the "story"; GameKiller346 posted 8 videos that cover the whole thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												My score: 2/10I should have known what I would think of the game from my first impression - I couldn't get the main menu to work correctly! I could highlight New Game, but was unable to access the Options menu. After playing the game for a little bit, I would go to the menu and was unable to access the "Save & Quit" option. I basically had to just wait until I got to a save point and then Ctrl+Alt+Delete to the Task Manager and End Task to quit the game... This was only the beginning.Game Mechanics were a big issue for me, which makes it even more problematic knowing that this is a platformer from start to finish. Timing the jumps is part of the game, but basically missing a jump means dying and dying means restarting, A LOT. But then there are other problems with the game mechanics. There is a part where you have to use geysers to jump from place to place. Although, I was finally able to get through it (simply by luck), I was never able to figure out how the mechanic actually worked to make it happen. Basically, I just kept pushing buttons and after 50 attempts, I'd finally make it. Additional problems are that this was an obvious port from X-Box (still had places to push X or Y buttons), that was badly adapted to a keyboard and mouse. Finally, there were levels that I was able to complete without doing (what I would think are) necessary actibities.  Don't want to spoil the game, but in multiple levels there are these huge machines to turn on to get from one point to another. I went explorting before doing this and managed to reach the end of the level. This is just poor level design. In a game that is all about exploring, I should be able to explore myself out of a level without doing crucial steps.The puzzles were a bit interesting. The problem was that they were generally the same puzzles time after time after time with very little variation between them. This almost seemed like cheating to me. Pick up stone, use it to power a machine. Walk for five minutes, pick up stone, use it to power another machine. Rinse, lather, repeat about 20 times. Opening doors? Find a code from six buttons. Next door? Same 6 buttons but in a different order. Next door? Guess what? Same 6 buttons but in a different order. This same puzzle for about 6-8 doors.The most annoying part of the game was all the pointless dying. There were areas where it is difficult to tell where you could and could not go, but if you went to a area you were not supposed to go to, you died. Restart. One level (without giving too much away) sees the player navigating through volcanic activity. This level took me a good 30-45 minutes to navigate because I could not tell what was going to kill me and what wouldn't kill me. By the time I finally got through it, I was so frustrated, I wanted to delete the game. Another part of the game involves plants killing you by coming out of the ground and there was no telling (other than dying) where some of them would appear from. It got annoying because I was frequently not even close to a clump of plants, but still managed to die by getting spiked. Restart.The story was somewhat interesting. It was the only thing that made me play through the game to the finish. However, it was so anti-climactic that I was disappointed when I finally finished it. Not even the world made want to keep gonig. I did not really find myself once thinking, I wonder what's around that corner, but wondered many times, what is THAT supposed to be? There was one level that (I think) had a glacier or ice on it, but it was so poorly implemented I don't know what it was. The biggest problem with the landscape development was that the rocky outcroppings and "boundaries" of the level were supposed to be stone, but looked smooth instead of rough and rock-like. Was it worth $20.00? Not even close. It took me roughly 6 hours to win the game and with all the problems described above, I'm not sure I'd really even pay $5.00 for the game. Maybe $1.99 if I had a free afternoon on a random Satruday. The only reason this did not get a 1/10 is because there weren't any game breaking bugs nor anytime the game crashed to desktop. So at least they got that right.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												A nice atmospheric story-rich simple game. It's not much game-play wise: you switch by just wandering around, balancing on tall structures, and jumping through rocks and platforms. There are a few very simple puzzles. The jumping part is fun, accompanied by low gravity.The atmosphere is spot on. Nice dark ambient soundtrack and visuals are unique, and good looking, although there could be more detail in certain more monotonic geographical areas of the game. The story is very good, rich in mystery and even emotion. In addition to the story there are some collectibles, which surprised me as they were accompanied by some intelligent information. The game world is divided into many short levels, all of which are very varied and some are absolutely astonishing in terms of atmosphere and visuals.The game is short and can be finished in five hours, unless you (like me) get drawn in by the atmosphere and want to explore every corner. Suggested to people who like post apocalyptic atmosphere and mystery.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Lifeless Planet certainly sold me on a unique premise.  An American Astronaut lands on a planet 30 light years from earth, only to discover that not only did the Soviet beat them there, but that they've all mysteriously disappeared...And so begins what is probably the best 'Walking Simulator' I've played in the last three years, and all the usual suspects of the genre are here; diary entries, simple puzzles, no enemies, and most importantly, an atmosphere so thick and intoxicating that it just makes the games many flaws all that more tragic.  The majority of the games 'walking' involves linear pathways with simplistic jumping challenges and the occasional 'put the battery in the battery slot' puzzle, while gravity and vegetation serve as the games biggest threats.  It's certainly more involved than the other mascots of the genre, like Gone Home and Dear Ester.The graphics in particular deserve attention.  Specifically, they're terrible.  Even while playing on the highest graphical settings it felt like I was playing a game from the middle of the PS2 era.  Hope you like your worlds full of terrain morphing, because that's what you're getting, texture stretching on cliffs and all.  This plain geology is broken up with some simple rock models here and there, but it's no where near enough to fix how bland some environments feel.  The man-made structures are a mixed bag.  The simple utilitarian houses are well modelled and fit the theme well, while the larger structures are blocky and kind of silly looking.  The character models are also horrendous, and have such a cheap, low quality appearance.The games plot is also a bit of a mixed bag.  Earlier parts of the game sprinkle bits of character back-story on you, before deciding the to leave that arc alone until the end game.  In fact, so many plot points occur in the opening segments of the game that a lot of the middle section simply feels like filler.  On the other hand, this 'quiet' gives the game, and the player, a chance to take in the scenery, and with a full play through lasting three and a half hours, it's not that big a deal.Even with the visual and story pacing issues, I found Lifeless Planet to be a generally pleasurable experience.  It's aura of mystery and discovery kept me interested enough to see it to the end.  That said, it's a bit steep at $20, so you're better off waiting for a sale or bundle deal.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												I'll be honest, it's not Game of the year potential but it is a nice platforming puzzle explorer. I didn't know the references in the story so it was largely new and quite interesting to me. The gameplay is consistent but not exactly great, turn rate in fine tuned platforming is kinda awkward but it does very well for it's jetpacking and puzzling elements. I also appreciated a new gadget that while not exactly original was well implemented. It's only about 2-3 hours long as well.Overall I'd say it's not really worth $20 but 10-15 is quite reasonable for my enjoyment. I liked the scifi story and the way it was built into the world. I liked the collectibles and the linear but not guided nature of the world. (There's usually only really one way to progress but it doesn't have a bigass arrow or a minimap pointing it out) The gameplay was good but not great in my opinion, although it seemed consistent and realistic. I think it's a little small but I'm under the impression it was one developer so for one person this is an awesome amount of material and story to put out and I was quite impressed. It won't revolutionize gaming and to be honest there are better indie games for less but this one is certainly a fine game that could be played on a day off. I'd probably give it a high 6 to 7/10 (my grading scale may be different from others, this is certainly passing respectably. 5/10 is my fail point personally.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												I was a little iffy about buying this game at first. I wasn't sure whether it would be worth the money or not. I read a couple really good reviews though, and the game was on sale, so I took it. Gotta say, it was a really good impulse buy. Very worth it.The game's atmosphere felt really mysterious, sometimes even a little creepy, and the planet was absolutely gorgeous (even being lifeless as it is). The game's more challenging sections were well spaced apart and even the "more challenging sections" as I am describing them, are not TOO challenging. You're never overwhelmed with super challenging obstacles or puzzles, but sometimes the game does make you think quite a bit.Now, every now and then you might find yourself wandering in circles, unsure of how to progress, but don't give up! The game is actually not that hard, and you just have to walk around for a bit and find out what you're supposed to do. And believe me, once you find out what to do, you may or may not smack yourself in the face and say "how did I not realize that I was supposed to do that?" or "that was there the whole time?!"As far as dying in the game: yes, you can. I won't say how, but you can die, yes. So be prepared for a lot of parts where you're trying to avoid dying by... whatever it is that can kill you (no spoilers :3 except fall damage. I will say you can die by falling. It's also in this game's achievement list to do just that, so...).Overall, this game was absolutely fantastic. I don't know if I would buy it for $19.99 because really it's only roughly 3-5 hours of gameplay average (I beat it in just under 4 hours, even with getting stuck at a few parts and wandering around for minutes trying to find out what to do to progress) and is really only good for one playthrough I think, but I got it on sale for $9.99 and I think that was a good price for it. I say it's only good for one playthrough because once you know what's going on, you've read the documents along the way, and you finish the game, that's kinda just it. There's not too much reason to play it again, unless you want to search every inch of the game for all the hidden science-y samples you can collect, if that's your thing. I guess if you miss out on the Rocketeer achievement you may want to play again without reading the documents so you can beat the game faster (you have to beat it in under 4 hours to get that achievement) but other than just getting the achievements for sh*ts and giggles, I think one playthrough is enough to satisfy your needs.However, don't think that you shouldn't get the game just for that reason. That one playthrough, for me, was a true adventure, and one of the most fun experiences I've ever had with gaming. I haven't played a game like this one in forever, and I really really enjoyed every step of my journey, which truly felt like an immersive journey. That's really all I have to say about this game. Basic rundown: The planet was absolutely gorgeous, I loved the scenery, the challenges aren't TOO challenging, you may get lost but don't give up, and the backstory was very interesting (READ THE DOCUMENTS! DON'T YOU DARE SKIP OVER THEM! I WILL FIND YOU AND MOO IN YOUR FACE VERY OBNOXIOUSLY IF YOU DO!)Overall: 10/10 stars. Just yes. I really had a lot of fun on my journey. I recorded a video for YouTube and will add the link to my review soon, but I have to edit and upload it still, so my playthrough isn't up there just yet, but it will be, once I get around to it.

Posted: December 29, 2016
												This game is fairly short ... I finished it in 6 hours, but I felt I got my money's worth and then some.  As a puzzle/platformer game it is engaging and fun. None of the puzzles or platformer jumps were frustrating. Some were obvious, and others took a few tries.  The controls were solid. I never felt like I died or screwed up a jump because of the game itself ... I was always able to retry and get the timing right.  It was a good balance that made it fun and relaxing to play. Never frustrating, not too challenging, but just challenging enough.The game design is quite good at nudging you along the correct path, but still giving the sense that you're "exploring" a vast world. You're  probably not going to get stuck in a section trying to figure out what to do next.  I felt more like I was part of an interactive piece of art, and actively making the story unfold.Overall I'm quite happy with this game. It was six hours well spent, and I'd like to give it a second play-through later.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game if, like me, you are playing on a PC with a left-handed mouse, and tend to remap key bindings from WSAD configuration to something else. The game DOES support using the cursor keys to control your character, but DOES NOT support remapping any of the other keys. The need to combine the space key for jumping with camera control by left-handed mouse and cursor keys for movement is so awkward that this game becomes unplayable, considering that it requires very precise jumping.Too bad, because I was really interested in experiencing this game's story.I really do not understand why developers are willing to spend so much time on developing a game and then do not allow key remapping, which is quite easy to implement. Effectively, they are shutting out about 10% of their player base.

												There is a Myst-like quality to Lifeless Planet. I mean this in the most flattering way. The game offers very little in terms of challenge, and it can get quite repetitive, but as interactive storytelling it works quite well. It helps that some of the alien landscapes on the Premier Edition, like the volcanic Inferno level, are truly breathtaking at first glance (hence the Myst comparison). If anything threw me off it was the character models, which look as if they could've used a little more design or better texturing. But considering this is mostly the work of one guy, David Board, I am willing to be lenient. Bottom line: Lifeless Planet is a nice short trip that may or may not stick with you, but either way you'll be glad you decided to take it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Before I say anything, consider this: the game was basically built by one guy. That’s a tremendous amount of work considering, that it’s a 6-hour game. GameplayIt’s a very-very-VERY simple game, more like a simulator where you control this little man in a space suit. He moves around and jumps, on occasions interacts with simple objects and that’s about it. It doesn’t have much of a character. He does comment on his surroundings at times and reads some documents that he finds but it’s nothing close to a fully developed character to have a bond with.The game itself is noticeably uneven, being exciting and tight in the beginning and getting more and more stretched out, unoriginal as you progress. About half-way through the game I started to feel impatience when again I saw some long distances that had to be covered just for the sake of extending playtime. The last chapters felt plain empty to say the least. I also felt that so-familiar irritation that bug games like Alice: Madness Returns – you know the time when you have to jump from one ledge to another but the normal jump is too short whereas the double jump leaps you way over it and into the abyss below. Be ready to swallow a decent amount of this.Other than that it’s working, doesn’t crash and if taken as it is – a simple game, then you won’t be disappointed.DesignThe game felt like Kairo. It could have been named ‘Kairo 2’ or ‘Before Kairo’ or something. This means that the environment felt very artificial and made of elements that don’t blend so well with each other. Now, that might be a good thing. This way you can create a game that feels abstract and Lifeless Planet, despite of it’s realistic setting de jure, felt abstract. The elements felt unnatural and out of place, think of it as Dadaism or postmodernism in art. In Lifeless Planet this conflict felt deliberate.  Everybody knows what a lifeless planet looks like, right? It’s a barren wasteland of sand and craters. The game starts out with the common idea of such a planet but how long can you show this before the player tires? No long. So, in every new chapter the design does get a little more daring, yes still trying to hold on to a sane image of a wasted planet and it was curious and funny to observe how the designer gave in to more and more of absurdities until it became a complete fantastical vista. This makes you give credit to games like Borderlands and Rage, which managed to hold it together.If you happen to have played with Unity’s terrain creator then you will get some flashbacks from the kitchen side of game development. I never noticed that in a game before and can’t say that I liked it. It felt like seeing the first clumsy experiments of a digital painter who tries out Photoshop’s default brushes.VerdictAfter all the whining and complaining I still recommend the game. Why? Because it felt chill and because then you know what one person with little help is able to create. Most of all I disliked the running around but everything else I’m ready to accept. I have far deeper issues with games from bigger companies.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Overall, I thought this was a pretty good game.  You play an astronaut exploring a planet, but it's pretty linear -- for the most part, you're following a relatively fixed path and having to solve a few puzzles along the way to progress.  The story is kind of interesting, but there didn't seem to be a whole lot of it; there's enough to keep things moving, but it's told in small pieces with longer stretches of silence (well, environmental sounds) in between.  It took me around 9-10 hours to get through the game, looking up some info/hints when I got stuck in a few places, and generally not too difficult.  But around the middle of the game, one sequence of ~7 jumps in a row had me stuck for a long time (easily 30+ minutes of play time).  I knew what to do, but had a lot of trouble actually doing it and that really annoyed me.  That could just be me and my game-playing skills, but that part really disrupted my enjoyment of the game.  I eventually got past it and finished the game, but it just wasn't quite the same after that point.  I was a little disappointed to find out that I had missed some things along the way (I still hadn't earned some achievements), and you only get a single save point that's automatically determined by the game as you go, so I'd have to start all over again from the beginning again if I wanted to look for what I missed.  Yes, there's some replay value here, but having seen the story and everything once already, I'm not sure I'd enjoy it as much when I'd really just be looking to find some missing pieces / get some achievements.  Also note that once you finish the game, it's impossible to "resume game" from the main menu; it just crashes.  I was hoping to go back and see the ending bit again, but I'd have to play the whole game again now to do so.  :(  So as I said at the start, I think this game is good overall, and would recommend it if it sounds interesting to you or you generally like games of this type.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												I bought it probably because there was a discount on it once on Steam and I just kept it in my libary for a while.I was playing it recently. To hell with those outdated graphics, but the game is not even optimized properly. I played it on my laptop whch runs Far Cry 3 with at least 30 FPS. But somehow my laptop was struggling with Lifeless Planet and the framerate was sometimes dropping below 20. You can choose the graphics quality from "Fastest" to "Fantastic", but there was no significant difference, so I kept it on lowest settings.But what about gameplay? Well, there we go. At the beginning it got me intrigued with the story so I kept playing, but as you go deeper into the game it turns out to be a platformer with poor (or lazy?) level design. And the plot turns into some kind of low budget sci-fi that you don't even have to bother about, because to most of it you have to read from the notes found around.Also the controls are not sharp, therefore there are some platforming you will repeat over and over due to that issue until you get it right. Otherwise it's just walking through a tunneled and long paths that are just boring. That's also because the character you control is slow and runs like he♥♥♥♥♥♥himself in his spacesuit.There are puzzles too, but they're not very challenging and won't take you longer than couple minutes to figure out and are usually repetetive, so all you'll have to focus on is to where to find the objects needed to solve the riddle.I guess somebody was too ambitious with making an indie game. It is a very mediocre independent game, but if you take note of the price, it is actually quite poor.3/10

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I had this pleasure of playing this at PAX 2012 with the creator and it has not failed to capture my attention again. Don't let the deceptively austere environment fool you - there is a high amount of detail and the atmosphere helps build the mysteriousness of the story. As for audio, music is sparse - in a good way. The tracks build slowly and help illuminate the progress you've made. I really enjoy exploring open-world environments to find hidden secrets, and this game rewards you with bits and pieces of information relevant to the story. You can die, as I did during a variety of the platforming style puzzles, but thankfully a checkpoint system is in place that doesn't put you too far back from your current position. It's unusual for a game to have no interface on-screen, but it really helps heighten the enjoyment of the overall ambience the game is trying to exude. I love everything about it so far, and am so excited to see what else is in store!

content:
Posted: February 26
												There is a Myst-like quality to Lifeless Planet. I mean this in the most flattering way. The game offers very little in terms of challenge, and it can get quite repetitive, but as interactive storytelling it works quite well. It helps that some of the alien landscapes on the Premier Edition, like the volcanic Inferno level, are truly breathtaking at first glance (hence the Myst comparison). If anything threw me off it was the character models, which look as if they could've used a little more design or better texturing. But considering this is mostly the work of one guy, David Board, I am willing to be lenient. Bottom line: Lifeless Planet is a nice short trip that may or may not stick with you, but either way you'll be glad you decided to take it.

												Ok lets start with the end: is it worth the asking price? Considering what other games you could get on Steam for the same price id say definitely not worth the aksing price.What kind of game this is?It is built on the base of a walking simulator, with very good atmosphere added to it and more importantly, a very good story.There is not much else i could add, basically the gameplay treats you, the player, as a mouse in a maze, thats all there is to it, just find the right way in the maze to get your mouse food...namely advance the story, which its quite interesting, so the reward for your mouse-in-the-maze endeavour is quite good, no complaints there.Wont take you more than 7-8 hrs to finish the game, and the gameplay is basically find your way through a maze...sounds bad...but it isnt, because this game is more than the sum of its parts.The saving grace is a very good idea for the story and a very good atmosphere.A memorable little game that i recommend with all my heart, but definitely NOT for the full price, i wish the developer came to his senses and priced his game in accordance to other steam games, which will allow more players to enjoy it.

												Overall, the game had an interesting storyline, and could have had more to pull the player in towards the end of the game. Starting the game, you are riveted to the actions of everything around you, and you want to know the truth about this place that you have landed. But, as the truth comes out - the game loses a lot of its mystery. It is still a stunning puzzle/platformer, and I was able to enjoy my playthrough of this game. Now, onto pros/cons.Pros: Can run on almost any computer, yet still beautifulDecent storylineGood control schemeDecent voice actingWide open world to exploreGood execution and introduction of morals through story driven text itemsRussian women (hehe)Cons:Enemies become very repetitiveToo many similar puzzlesThe story fades in intensity as it progressesClunky animationsStory is shortNow, with everything listed above - I would recommend this game. If it's on sale, its a good way to get through less than 4 hours of gameplay, and still be left thinking about ideas and morals brought up through the progression of the story.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Some things can be done better but I have genuinely enjoyed the whole game as an exploratory experience. The game generates great views of the planet landschafts, which change from chapter to chapter not allowing your get bored. I can agree with other reviewers that puzzles are rather simplistic and not much of a challenge, but that's not the point really. One thing was actually bugging me through the most of the game - rewards for exploration. The game start off with a promise that exploring every corner and small hidden pathways would bring a reward in a form of found samples or artifacts with a small explanation or story behind. This puts you in a mood of explorer initially, but the game subsequently fails to deliver on this promise. After 3rd chapter I believe, I couldn't find a single sample, note or artifact anywhere no matter how hard I was looking around, I was finding perfect places to hide such things with zero result. This really puts you off and exploring becomes a joke. Add to this a completely linear gameplay and you'll understand why there are no many bad reviews. There are invisible walls around areas and in some cases camera would just stop following you so you can not go further. Really? Isn't it so impossible hard to put some "natural" walls or cliffs or something that prevent me from going further instead invisible walls that I really hate in games.In any case, this game could be absolutely awesome if there would be more freedom, more exploration, more elaborate storyline, more "unknown" (even not related to the main story line, man we are on alien planet!) to explore and study. Something like a soil scanner would cool to have to investigate surrounding areas in search for clues. Nevertheless I really enjoyed this game with all its drawbacks, so thumbs up! Hope the next game from this studio will deliver a deeper experience, lots of promise here!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I was looking forward to playing this.  It looked beautiful, and supposedly had a compelling story, complete with mystery and a sci-fi sort of feel to it.  What I got was 8 hours of walking through deserts, and a few notes about how the humans destroyed this planet almost as soon as they arrived.  Gameplay: Walk, run, and occasionally die at the same platform leap every time.  About 5 (very easy) puzzles in the whole game, I don't think I spent even 15 minutes total on puzzles.  Platforming, a few very very VERY tricky jumps but mostly a clear line where there's only one possible path to take, high above everything else so it stands out.  Walk, follow the green track (or footprints), avoid traps that are off to the sides of the footprints.  Walk across dunes. Walk across rocks. Walk up hills.  Walk alongside a canyon.  Walk up to a building. Find a note outside. All the doors are boarded up, so continue walking.Story: *SPOILERS* (well as much as there is anything to spoil anyway)I'm on this planet. My crew is missing. Oh there's an abandoned soviet town. Oh my crew is dead.  Oh the soviets are dead. Oh the planet is dead.  The notes say the Soviets killed everything on the planet because they used the sole energy source for power.  Humans kill everything.  Wait, there's one woman! Follow her.  Walk.Super game breakers:I might have still enjoyed the game except for the jarring limits placed on me.  Oxygen ALWAYS runs out when there's a refill exactly far enough away that I almost pass out right when I reach it.  Oxygen refills last 8 (in game) hours, or overnight and half of the next day.  Jetpack ALWAYS gets a booster right before I have to make a series of long jumps.  The booster will last until I make the last jump in the set, and run out immediately afterward.  The boosted jetpack was lots of fun, two levels made great use of it's superior platforming abilities.    The world looks HUGE until you realize that there's invisible walls preventing you from getting too far off track.  (With the exception of the forest level where I wandered around in mist for a full hour until I rage quit, looked up a walkthrough, STILL couldn't find the way out, and finally found the answer on a forum here on Steam).  Most of the game felt like the creators were pushing me into one path and saying "Go THAT way! And get there on THIS path! Don't look for shortcuts, we're taking your climbing ability."The "Save and Quit" function is broken. The only way to quit was ALT/F4 or Task Manager -> End Task.  The save might put you back a level when you restart the game.  In-Game options don't work. Overall:Graphics - 9Platforming - 5 (some levels 0, some levels 8)Story - 3Puzzles - 2Submersion - NonexistentGameplay - 4 (A few good sections boosted it)I would not have bought this if any of the descriptions had showed what to expect.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												If you're a fan of the Stalker series or Andrei Tarkovsky's oeuvre you might enjoy this... or you might come away from it feeling like the developer shot for Solaris (1972) and came up Solaris (2002), patching the cracks with a narrative epoxy derived from the bargain bin of Lost (2004) instead of the deeper and more consistent Eastern European science fiction referenced throughout.Early visual teases evoking Pink Floyd's Momentary Lapse of Reason set a misleading supernatural tone that undermines the science fiction bedrock of the narrative.  Key gameplay elements function as foreshadowing - if you see an oxygen drop in the distance you'll learn you have just enough time to beeline for it before you die; when you find jetpack fuel you know it'll run out as soon as you've cleared the jumping puzzle that it portends.  Air and propellant are otherwise infinite, which neatly avoids the tedium of "survival" resource management.  Jump cuts between levels are frequently immersion-breaking and serve as reminders that despite a very Open World feel, Lifeless Planet is a linear platformer with few, if any, rewards for exploration beyond the path set by the narrative.Pretty, minimal, and functional, with very low replay value - Lifeless Planet is a short game and a short story.  The brief runtime (or rather, walktime) combined with shallow gameplay and a personal distaste for certain elements of the narrative lead me to not recommend the game at the list price, though I certainly recommend checking it out it when it's on sale.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												I started out loving this game, about half way through it turned to strong like, by the end it was an okay game. The idea is great but there are glitches and issues that hinder the playthrough that really really frustrated me. First is the controls: in the main menu I had issues where the highlighted section never moved (made exiting the game a job for end task). Then i had some issues with the jump function. It would be delayed (though the game ran fine). Second was the achievements: one is (as far aas anyone can figure) not unlockable. This is the Planet Historian one. Either there is a glitch where the documents dont appear or just not for PC. Also for some of them you need to do it on your first playthrough. Turns out you can delete saved games and it will count again as "first" playthrough. I dont like deleting saved games so that was sucky. However, the plot is interesting and definitely moves the game along well. And even though some might complain about distances you have to walk I thought it was a great way to represent how large and empty the world was. Plus jet pack fun!6/10

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Lifeless Planet (BETA) Review 

			Views: 632		

			Review of Lifeless Planet for PC. You can find written review at http://www.heavenforgamers.com Lifeless Planet Walkthrough Playlist:...		

Originaly done for http://www.heavenforgamers.com (Nearly Finished).The Early Access build which I’m currently reviewing is now around 3 months old and the game has moved on significantly from what I’ve found. The full version of the game will be noticeably different and should be released on 6th June this year.This game was developed by one man army – David Board, who was based in Alaska in time when I was getting preview code which apparently should make game experiance even more amazing .Game is platform adventure with puzzle elements to solve while levels are unfortunately mostly linear but thankfully to good level design you will have feeling that everything around you is completely open and full of secrets. Apparently game was originally planned to be a action platformer but in my opinion with good decision from David Board this game went to different road where story is in main focus. Game was inspired by LucasArt’s’s The dig and Another World, also by Cold War sci-fi movies posing questions about humankind’s desire for space travel.You are taking roll of USA astronaut, waking up on far and unknown planet with ship wreck around. You are unable to find any of your crew while everything around is completely empty without any living soul except dust, wind and your needs for oxygen.Although with that being said planet isnt completely in sand-brown colour pallet, in fact soon after begining game gives you not so lifeless mountain ranges and flats where you can clearly see designer skills. The interiors of levels are also surprisingly well rendered, which provides some of the creepiest moments through whole thing.Eventually through your journey you will find out that this isnt really completely uninhabitable planet, while you are going to search for your crew you will stamble on abandon city full with old houses, a lot of russian logs where you are going to learn more about events which happened somewhere in time before our protagonist arrived on this planet. Seems like that Russians won space race after all ?Experiments, green footsteps, mechanical arms and systems for activating devices which were suited for slim and much taller beings rather then for people are only one part of discovery which will take your mind on couple different thoughts about who or rather what made this wasteland as it is now.How and when Russians found way to this planet ? How at first place they even brought that amount of people to build whole city or even more ? Hallucinations about empty beds perhaps even a russian girl who appears here and there, are complete mystery to everyone.At current stage of the game you will not find any settings related to controls beside Invert Vertical Look and Auto Center Camera while ingame settings offers and Higher Quality Effects option. Another problem which can be quite frustrating for some people is not being able to strafe properly which kinda limits your observation while you are running in some direction but still it can be done after couple minutes of practicing.Beta and currently available unfinished version is released on March 6th 2014 and includes only first six chapters from 20 expected overall which will provide you around 2 hours of gameplay if you are playing for first time and around 40 minutes of just rushing through the game.Release date is only in couple days from now so be prepared for Lifeless Planet which might not be so Lifeless after all.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												The game Lifeless Planet is one that feels like it has potential, but ultimately falls short.The story seems like it could be fascinating, but unless you take the time to go out of your way to search out every single tape in the game you are left with something that feels fairly generic at best.The game mechanics that are presented seem to work fairly well, but they're all things we've seen a thousand times before (with the possible exception of the robotic arm which was terribly under utilized). They really start to quickly feel samey.There are moments when you need to refill your oxygen tanks or top off your jetpack for some jumping puzzles which I felt were kind of hit-and-miss in their appeal. However, there isn't any kind of gauge or timer for either tank. You only need to bother with oxygen when the creators felt like having you worry about it at seemingly random points in the story. The jetpack also lacks any kind of gauge or limitation on it's longevity. You can try the puzzle and use as many boosts as you feel like all day long. But, no matter how quickly or slowly you solve a challenge, the jetpack's fuel level mysteriously goes low again a short distance away.The game feels like it has so much wasted potential. It's entertaining for a while, but quickly becomes dull and repetitive.If you want to try this game out, by all means do so. Just wait until it's steeply discounted in a sale.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Walk.  Walk some more.  Then walk.  You can only walk one way, the rest is wasting time.  Now jump.  Jump again.  Jump some more.  You can only jump one way, the rest is wasting time.  Follow the obvious path.  Walk.  Avoid the bad path.  Jump.  Jump higher.  Tricky jump.  Save point (yes, nowhere useful).  Press a button.  Wait for a moment.  Walk.  Jump.  Die.Repeat ad naseum.  Pretty.  But too linear.  Easy to control.  But quite boring.  Nicely created landscape.  But you can't explore it.It's okay.  But 1.5 hours in and I'm bored and this is after I've tried to die in interesting ways to see if there was an achievement.  And it's still going.

												I love it... Fun atmosphere.. Dont want it to end! cant wait for full release <-- Early access review. After playing the full game, the developers should be ashamed. The developer should refund the people who bought the early acess because that was exactly the same as the full release and lets face it, I saw no difference. It was great in  the beta, but for a full game release.. 3.5hrs of content just isnt worth it  The Content for the money just wasnt worth it in my opinion when you can get much more content in other games for $20. Story line shouldve went farther then it did as it was short to begin with, leaves a cliff hanger and there is no planned DLC or sequel. I feel like I wasted money. Shameful this game ended up cut short. It had potential and a really good atmosphere feeling when you played it but the developer seemed to just want to release it and make money quickly and cut the game short with minimal content. I would reccomend this if the price came down from its price when reviewed.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												I got the Humble Bundle mostly for this, I was disappointed.The beginning was alright, but then the game becomes a long chore of frustratingly easy and repetitive puzzles, bad platforming and some bad level design. Yes, the title has its merits, but there was hardly enough in here to make the game interesting or really stand out. So you end up reluctantly advancing while picking up logs and watching at some other stuff.If I had to put a finger on it, it is kinda like the Max Payne (1) dream sequence dragged out a lot in large parts. without the dizziness(except from the camera) or the horror-elements. Also there are levels that are just too dark and the brighten option hardly seemed to do anything.Tbh it became really boring in the end and I only finished it because I thought I had to.If you don't mind traveling over a countryside that looks in many places like the hills in Battlefield 1942 did, if you like exploring places that only occasionally yield another trifle to look at, if you don't mind kinda horrible platforming and some clunky mechanics and can immerse yourself in this, then get the game. I'd only recommend it like I got it, either in a bundle or in a sale with a huge discount.All in all it really just felt like a chore to me, which is kinda sad, because the initial idea was intriguing and I looked forward to this. In any case, I'll not replay it.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Best walking simulation ever. A brilliant idea and atmosphere failed at execution. Spoilers ahead Immersion: An American astronaut boosts his jetpack with a canister of something left on the planets surface at least on year 1976 without any tool or leaving his suit ?  Feels So RealEnvironment:There are only six types of objects you can interact with; boulders, barrels,  small green boulders which provides electricity for machinery if you " manage " to solve puzzles, explosives ( you use them only for three times  ), sort of buttons for machinery and rectangular stone tablets towards the end of the game.  So there is no interaction with environment. Any interaction has sole purpose of moving forward.Survival: There is a problem and it is shortage of oxygen. When you fill your tank it only last for 8 hours. The problem is 8 hours of what ? Game time ? Real time ? But soon you learn it is just a scripted event and you are always safe until pre-set points in the game thus a minimal surviving experience.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												This game is bad.  BAD.  It has a nice hook and draws you in so that you are constantly waiting for that one delivery that one story twist that will make it all worth it... and then never gives it to you.  The game starts with nothing and goes on a long walk of pointless minor puzzle solving and stupid multijump platforming to get you nowhere.  Nothing is resolved, nothing is solved, there isn't ever really any conflict or rising action or big question that ever gets answered in any way.  There are many, many disjointed story elements that apparantly have nothing at all to do with anything.The ending isn't bad or good its simply a non-entity that means nothing and does nothing.Here is an ending that does more and resolves more than the one they give you.  Your spaceship crashed and your helmet cracked on a dead lifeless planet and you hallucinate out the rest of the game before dying alone on the wretched planet.  The end.Or if your an optimist the whole game is a cold sleep dream before you arrive at the planet and get to explore it for real!  The end.Take your pick.  Both of those are better than what the game will give you.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												It's always both surprising and depressing when a video game uses only a single game mechanic for the entirety of it, and that mechanic is implemented as poorly as possible. I cannot even fathom what others here who claim that this game has no bugs played but it certainly wasn't Lifeless Planet. You see, this game is one of those which wants you to experience the views and vistas while having minimal interaction with anything else. No shooting, no big puzzles. Running and jumping. The story starts out very intruiging and leads to a sub-standard and cliche'd ending. Running and jumping at first seems enjoyable and even quite fun and exciting until you jump from one rock to another for the 1000th time and wish the game would throw something different at you already, or just end. The jumping mechanic itself is done as poorly as possible. Yes it works, but barely. I kept getting stuck on rocks and canyons and the almost non-existent air control after a jump mostly lead to an untimely death. The best thing about Lifeless Planet is the music and the artistic concept of some of the environments. Because even though technically this game is nothing to look up to, it definitely has great atmosphere and you almost always feel alone and helpless on an alien planet. The orchestrated music, as I previously mentioned, is brilliant. I would recommend listening to the soundtrack because along with the atmosphere, it's the only thing holding this game up. Definitely not worth full price and definitely not for those who are looking for a long or special experience. The abundance of graphical glitches and audio bugs (music and sfx would suddenly disappear in many of the levels) hold this title back from becoming a true triumph. Treat the game as a 5-hour experiment from a promising bunch of indie developers and you'll probably find something to like. If you approach it with hopes of experiencing anything above standard (except for the music) it will lead to sour disappointment.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Lifeless Planet is a walking simulator. Now normally I use that term as a kind of endearing, tongue-in-cheek term for narrative-driven exploration games like Dear Esther, Gone Home, etc. which I enjoy greatly. However Lifeless Planet is much closer to a literal going-for-a-walk simulator. You spend the vast majority of the game trundling along... well, a lifeless planet. The game is drab and brown and and boring looking. There are light platforming sections as well, which are serviceable but nothing really special. The jumping physics feel a bit off but don't get too frustrating. The excessive walking sections might be tolerable if paired with an interesting story (like "Eidolon") or beautiful visuals (like "Mind: Path to Thalamus"), but they're not. The story is mildly intriguing, but never really goes anywhere outside typical sci-fi fare, and journal logs and story tidbits are too few and far between. You spend most of the game chasing after a mysterious woman, even though you don't really know why other than "there's nowhere else to go". It just feels kind of aimless. It's a 5ish hour game, but it still feels like it drags on too long. It just wasn't my cup of tea.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Should be called "Lazy Level Design and Walking Simulator"Basically you walk around, jump onto a platform, walk around some more, listen to a very boring story, walk around, push a boulder underneath a platform, jump onto the boulder, jump onto the platform, walk some more, forget to grab a robot arm that you had no idea existed because the dev assumed you would walk up some stairs to a second floor of a building, get stuck somewhere, be incapable of getting that very important robot arm, some how get back, glitch through the floor, teleport back, walk around, jump, find some woman who can breath on a desert planet with no oxygen, start to run out of oxygen 7.8 hours before you were supposed to, find a coincidentally placed probe with oxygen, find a enemy at last, and realise that this enemy is completely stationary, and is easily avoidable, continue until you find the portal, relieved that the horror is done, find out that the portal is broken, walk more, find some deadly giant dandolions, jump on them, quickly jump onto a dead dandolion, quit, go type an angry review.That was my experience. The graphics are pretty bad, the animations are choppy, its boring, uninteresting, the "enemys" are just lazily made and make the same sounds every time they strike out with no pitch change even, and you will lose interest about 35 minutes in. I tried to finish it, I really did. But I just couldn't go on. I could finish it from where I left off in about 30 minytes to an hour. It trys to be a scary game by adding some "spooky" sounds and some dark areas where you need a flashlight to see.Edit: I came back to this game, somehow. Just more basic 3D platforming, bad story, and lazy enemies.2/10. Not worth the time, and $20 is just not worth it at all. Even Octodad is a better purchase.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												I read other's people reviews, and I'm still wondering if they played the same game that I did.I start the game, and the first thing I notice is the standard-Unity graphics configuration panel where you can pick your graphics details from "fastest" to "fantastic". Ominous, but to be fair there are nice Unity games out there.After going for "fantastic", strong in my hardware configuration, the second thing I notice is that the graphic is *not* fantastic. And oh! The game *lags and stutters* on the very first level.Don't get me wrong: I don't have a Steam-VR ready machine or anything, but I just finished Batman Arkham City, and *that* game (which indeed looked fantastic) ran at full detail in full-HD on my hardware, so the that the barren and (quite bad looking...) planet surface is proving too much for it, is just preposterous (even by Unity standards).The game is basically a platform: go through a level of obstacles (very plain and boring ones, with occasional annoying spikes in difficulty), with the aid of a broken jet-pack that gives only small boosts (which look like small farts ¡­), reach a building, get a clue. Rinse and repeat.Everything else in the game is heavily and (sloppily) scripted.Your character can have a very limited interaction with the world around him, and even that feels horribly clunky: you can push things, but the effect is all but satisfying and all you can do is give small pushes to objects (barrels, rocks, etc), not shove them around continuously. Guess implementing that, code-wise was too difficult :)Around the planet you'll find a number of Soviet recordings: you have an automatic translator, so your PDA will be brought up and you'll be able to read the content. Pity that the voice-over in russian is absolutely distracting, so you have to patiently wait for blabbering to stop, to be able to actually read (and in case it's not clear, I'm not having a go at Russian, as a language, but on the opportunity of having people talk while you try to read…)Occasionally you need to push a button.When you do, it's connected to a moving platform. Wait (for what will seem) an eternity for a it to arrive. Walk on it. Press another button (isn't that fun?!). Travel (painfully slowly) on the platform through a chasm, step down, and it's Farting Mario Bros all over again…Some other time you get some dynamite that you can use to destroy an obstacle. You pick it up, place it near the offending rock and go hide. 3.2.1. ­ Boom! You're dead. Why? Because the game does a rather basic check on the explosion (no ray-casting: maybe just a distance check?) and you where not in the right place, or at the right distance.But tt doesn't matter anyway: you'll just re-spawn nearby: the obstacle is removed and you get to even keep the dynamite that should have supposedly exploded, so you have you cake and you can eat it too!  Isn't that great? :DWater is your own kryptonite: you are walking in a pressurized suit (so you are basically a walking inflatable puppet), still you sink like a rock. [EDIT: as someone in the comments has correctly  pointed out, space suits *do* sink, so this one is on me. Not that it changes the overall judgment much...]The graphic is plain and unassuming, when it's not just bad. The only two NPC in the game, your wife and another woman, are a thing of nightmare.To give an example of how bad the graphic can just be, early in the game, there is a huge vent with a rotating fan. Put some sort of hard garbage while it's spinning and get through it: classic. The vent is just plain horrible to look at, the aforementioned physics is embarrassing and, in the end, even the vent's explosion seem to be ripped directly from a Half Life 1 era game.There are a lot of interesting settings on the planet: a small village, a long big hulking building near a chasm, etc, but you can't actually visit them: you can just look at them, pick some hint that might be laying around, and that's it. Farewell.I dutifully jumped and farted my way through the game, but the mechanics where atrocious, dull and repetitive, the graphics plain, the story not so good that you might feel hard pressed to move on, and the final attempts at introspection and at pulling som "2001 Space Odissey" s..t, laughable.I just wanted the game to finish and get over with it, but it kept shoveling at me the same repetitive stuff over, and over. I don't know if I hated more this game for the boring chore it is, or for the wasted potential, of what it could have been.The sound compartment is adequate, though still on the boring side. At some point during one of the lava background noise samples, I heard someone coughing. I don't know if on purpose.This is a horrible game, probably the worst game I played in more than a decade, and I regret every minute I spent on it so don't make the same mistake that I did, and stay clear from it: it's not worth it, even if you get it for free.The promotional text says: "Equipped with a limited-use jet-pack and a mobile robotic arm, the player must use wits and skill to solve puzzles, unravel the mystery, and survive the Lifeless Planet!". Please…AWFUL.AWFUL.AWFUL.

number of helpful: 19 of 37 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												This could have been a great game or even the best game of last four years if the original idea (Soviet colony in Earth-like planet, kept secret from the world, USA discovers the planet and sends an expedition team) was developed properly. It could have been a new universe for gaming, even may expanding into RPGs, strategy games, MMOs, fanfiction and comics. Instead of building upon this great idea which allows a variety of paths to take about story-writing, it turns out to be dull and somewhat cliche (human greed ruins everything) plot and it kinda ruined the experience for me as only thing I knew before buying was the original idea.I was actually pretty excited when I first saw the utility poles upon setting foot upon the planet, my excitement doubled then I discovered the colony and in the first hour I deeply felt isolated. But upon seeing how linear and pointless the story and mechanics is my excitement turned into a giant sigh followed by forcing myself to complete the game.Gameplay and UI is pretty clunky, even the Save&Quit button on the main menu was not working for me. This is a walking simulator with some puzzle platformer elements thrown in, but those additions felt more like chores to do for me as most of them were pretty easy and rest of them were just easy.I enjoyed only 1.5 hour of my 6 hours of gameplay time (story ruined by human greed thing, "wife" and the game's perception of other life forms, isolation feeling ruined by swiftly attacking roots) so I will give this 2.4/10 which should be pretty fair, as maths is always fair.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I wished the reviews would've been more objective. Sadly they weren't. That's what I can say after paying 20€ and 7 hours of playtime for my first playthrough. The thing is, you can literally feel what the creator tried to accomplish. He had a story in mind, a great story. But it seems he wasn't able to translate it into the game. So it ended up in being a walking simulator. I expected a melancholic scenery, maybe with a good puzzle here and there, but I was just walking and walking and walking and mostly nothing in between and I was always thinking (and hoping) that something will happen because the last thing that happened was an hour ago. Conclusion, it started good, the last scenarios in the game were good and interesting, but the middle part was just boring. Nothing what I would call a puzzle and a relatively empty world (what was intended, but it's too empty). I almost feel bad writing such a negative review, but it's definitely not worth 20 bucks. And that makes me angry because I know the game could've been so much better. Much much better. Nonetheless, I appreciate what the developer was trying to create. Try it when it's on sale for 5. It's definitely something different.

content:
Posted: February 24
												I recommend this game, but with a few caveats. The original premise that I bought it for went largely unfulfilled and the game turned out to be just jumping puzzles. I bought it thinking it would be an engaging exploration story, and instead it was just endless jumping puzzles. I played a couple hours, put it down for two months, then finished it off in another two hour session. While the game had atmosphere and piqued my curiosity, I was bored with the whole thing before it was over and playing just to finish it. What started out as an intriguing puzzle about space, time, and this planet, was quickly eclipsed by boring repetitive game play. It felt like an idea that was stretched out far beyond whatever potential it had, and left thin and wanting.However the game was beautiful, and there were times when I did marvel at the level design and enjoy what I was playing. By the time I was done though, these positives were outweighed by boredom. On the whole, if this is on sale it's worth a buy, but don't expect much. It also has zero replay-ability in my mind.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I haven't finished the game yet, but I sincerely doubt the ending of the game is going to fix any of its issues. First of all, the premise is actually quite interesting. You crash land on a planet that is supposed to be full of vibrant life and oxygen levels close to Earth's, but instead you get a barren wasteland with no air. Right off the bat, you discover a deserted Russian colony, which should not be possible, as you're the first people landing on this planet after a 15 year journey. As story settings go, this one is pretty damn solid. The only problem is, the characters suck. Straight away, the main character is bombarded with situations both deadly and bizzare and 90% of the time he won't even bat an eyelash. For somebody who saw his crew die violently in front of him, he is pretty damn composed and that screws with immersion so bad! You're supposed to empathise with the guy you're playing, but most of the time I just wonder what the hell is wrong with him. If the game was trying to put all its chips on atmosphere and playing experience, the complete lack of emotion really kills it. The secondary character, who you follow for the entire game, is just as uninteresting, except she speaks in Russian.In terms of gameplay, there are no new or exciting elements in Lifeless Planet. For most of the game, you're just jumping around. I wouldn't really call the obstacles in front of you puzzles, since they are entirely too simple. You just move from spot A to spot B, jump over some cliffs and enjoy the scenery. Skill is not really a factor in this one - if you happen to die to something, you just make a mental note of it and any sense of danger is gone. You also get get a robotic hand at some point, but that fails to inject even the smallest bit of fun. Without a single mechanic to pull you into the game, it gets boring VERY fast. Lifeless Planet is not worth the asking price of $20.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												A brisk run through clocking in under 4 hours for a first playthough. The game holds up well in the beginning, decent writing and pacing, but as the game stretches on the pieces of engaging story or backstory become much less common. There are very long stretches of platforming with very little to recommend them. The character doesn't respond or move sufficiently to make those segments entertaining in and of themselves. Adding to the general clumsiness of the platforming is the fact that some sections, one in particular, have regions where merely stepping on the wrong area of a platform ends up in instant death and the coloration differences from "Safe" to "Dead" are so small as to be unnoticable. The intro and beginning are an EXCELLENT use of affordances to have the player move in the right direction and find parts of the story and history of the Lifeless Planet, but these disappear later in the game leaving a frustrating feeling of trial and error in some portions.Overall the platforming and frustration of getting through various stages could be forgiven if the story and engagement of the first hour or so had held up. From about 1/3 in until about the last 15 minutes there's precious little to find or do other than follow a linear path of jumping and occasionally pushing buttons until something happens. For a first shot at a game I think it did better than I would have expected, but the first 1.5 hours or so is undoubtably the best part simply for how the exploration and mystery are handed to the player. The rest is just abyssmal.
